¶ Ye han erred also / for ye ne han nat examyned youre conseil in the forseyde manere / ne in due manere / as the cas requyreth
¶ Ye han erred also / for ye han maked no diuision bitwixe youre conseilours / this is to seyn / bytwixe youre trewe freendes / ⁊ youre feyned conseilours /
ne ye ne haue nat knowe thewyl / of youre trewe freendes / olde / and wise /
but ye han cast alle hir wordes / in an hochepot ⁊ enclyned youre herte / to the moore part ⁊ to the gretter nombre / ⁊ ther be ye condescended ▽
And sith ye woot wel / þᵗat men shal alwey fynde / a gretter nombre of foolis / than of wise men /

and therfore / the conseils þᵗat ben at congregacions / and mul
titudes of folk/ ther as men take moore reward / to the nōmbre / than to the sapience of persones /
ye se wel / þᵗat in swyche conseillynges / foolis han the maistrie
¶ Melibeus answerde agayn / and seyde / I graunte wel þᵗat I haue erred /

but ther as thow hast toold me her biforn / þᵗat he ne is nat to blame / þᵗat chaungeth his con
seillours / in certeyn cas / ⁊ for certeyne Iuste causes /
I am al redy / to chaunge my conseilours / right as thow wolt deuyse ▽

The ꝓprouerbe seith / that for to do synne / is mannysshhumanum / but certes / for to perseuere longe in synne
is werk of the deuel

¶ To this sentence / answerde anon dame Pru
dence / ⁊ seyde ▽

Examyneth quod she youre con
seil / ⁊ lat vs se / the whiche of hem / han spoken moost resonably / ⁊ taught yow best conseil /
And for as muche / as þᵗat the examinacion is necessarie / lat vs bigynne / at the Sirurgiens / and at the Phisiciens / þᵗat first speeken in this matere ▽

I sey yow þᵗat the Sirurgiens ⁊ Phisiciens / han seyd yow in youre con
seil / discretly / as hem oghte /
And in hir speche / seyden ful wysly / that to the office of hem / aperteneth / to doon to euery wight honour ⁊ ꝓprofit. and no wight to anoye /

and after hir craft to doon gret diligence vn-to the cure of hem / whiche þᵗat they han in hir gouern
ance
¶ And sire / right as they han answered wysly ⁊ discretly /
right so rede .I. / þᵗat they be heighly ⁊ souereynly gerdoned / for hir noble speche /
and eek for they shullen / do the moore ententif bisynesse / in the curacioūn of thy doghter deere ▽
For al be it so / that they ben youre freendes / therfore shal ye nat suffren / þᵗat they serue you for noght.
but ye oghte / the rather gerdone hem / ⁊ shewen hem youre largesse ▽
And as touchynge the proposicioūn / which þᵗat the Physiciens / encresceden in this cas / this is to seyn /
that in maladies / that a contᵃrarie / is warisshed / by another contrarie
I wolde fayn knowe / how ye vnderstande thilke text ⁊ what is youre sentence
¶ Certes quod Melibeus / I vnderstonde it in this wise ▽
that right as they han doon me a contᵃrarie / right so / sholde I / doon hem another /
for right as they han venged hem on me / ⁊ doon me wrong right so / shal I venge me vp-on hem / ⁊ doon hem wrong
⁊ thanne haue I cured / a contᵃrarie by another
¶ Lo / lo / quod dame Prudence / how lightly is euery man enclyned / to his owene desir / and to his owene plesance ▽
Certes quod she / the wordes of the Phisiciens / ne sholde nat han ben vnderstonden / in that wise ▽
for certes wikkednesse / is nat contrarie to wikkednesse / ne vengeance / to vengeance / ne wrong to wrong but they ben semblable ▽

And ther
fore / .o. vengeance is nat warisshed / by another venge
ance / ne .o. wrong by another wrong
but euerich of hem encresceth / ⁊ aggreggeth oother
¶ But certes / the wordes of thise Phisiciens / sholde ben vnderstonde / in this wise ▽

For good ⁊ wikked
nesse / ben two contᵃraries / and pees ⁊ werre / venge
ance ⁊ suffrance / discord ⁊ acord / and many othere thynges ▽
But certes / wikked / shal be warisshed by goodnesse / discord. by acord / werre. by pees / and so forth of othere thynges ▽

And her to / acordeth Seynt
Poul the Apostle / in many places /
he seith / Ne yeldeth noght harm for harm / ne wikked speche / for wikked speche /
but do wel / to hym þᵗat dooth to thee harm / ⁊ blesse hym / þᵗat seith to thee harm /
And in manye othere places / he amonesteth pees ⁊ acord

¶ But now wol I speke to yow / of the con
seil / which þᵗat was yeuen to yow / by the men of lawe / ⁊ the wise folk
þᵗat seyden alle by oon acord / as ye han herd bifore ▽
That ouer alle thynges / ye shal do youre diligence to kepe youre persone / ⁊ to warnestore youre hous /
⁊ seyden also / þᵗat in this cas ye oghten for to werke / ful auysely / ⁊ with greet deliberacioūn
¶ And sire / as to the firste point that toucheth / to the kepyng of youre persone /
ye shul vnderstonde / that he þᵗat hath werre / shal euere moore deuoutly ⁊ mekely / preyen / byforn alle thynges /
þᵗat Ihesus crist of his mercy / wol han hym in his pꝓproteccion / ⁊ ben his souereyn helpyng at his nede
¶ for certes in this world / ther is no wight þᵗat may be conseilled ne kept suffisantly / with oute the kepyng of oure lord IhūIhesu Crist
¶ To this sentence / acordeth the ꝓprophete Dauid / that seith /
If god ne kepe Citee / in ydel / waketh he þᵗat it kepeth
¶ Now syre / thanne shul ye / cōmmitte the kepyng of youre persone / to youre trewe freendes / þᵗat been approued and yknowe /
⁊ of hem / shul ye axen help / youre persone for to kepe ▽ For Catoūn seith / If thou hast nede of helpe / axe it of thy freendes /
for ther nys noon so good a Phisicien / as thy trewe freend
¶ And after this / thanne shul ye kepe yow / fro alle straunge folk ⁊ fro lyeres / ⁊ haue alwey / in suspect hir compaignye
¶ For Piers Alfonce seith / Ne taak no compaignye / by the wey / of a straunge man / but if so be / þᵗat thow haue knowe hym / of a lenger tyme /

And if so be / þᵗat he falle in-to thy compaignye / par
auenture / with-outen thyn assent.
enquere thanne / as subtilly as thow mayst of his conuersacioūn / ⁊ of his lyf bifore / And feyne thy wey / Sey þᵗat thow wolt go thider / as thow wolt nat go /
And if he bereth a spere / hoold thee on the right syde / And if he bere a swerd / hoold thee on the left syde
¶ And after this / thanne shal ye kepe yow wysly / from al swich manere peple / as I haue seyd bifore / ⁊ hem ⁊ hir conseil eschewe
¶ And after this / thanne shal ye kepe yow in swich manere /
that for any presumpcion of youre strengthe / þᵗat ye ne despise nat ne attempte nat the myght of youre Aduersarie / so lite / þᵗat ye lete / the kepyng of youre persone / for youre presumpcioūn /
for euery wys man / dredeth his enemy

And Salomon seyth
¶ Weleful is he / þᵗat of alle hath drede ▽
For certes he þᵗat thurgh the hardynesse of his herte / ⁊ thurgh the hardynesse of hym self hath to gret presumpcion / hym shal yuel bityde
¶ Thanne shal ye euere mo countrewayte emboyssementz ⁊ al espiaille
¶ For Senek seith / þᵗat the wise man þᵗat dredeth harmes / escheweth harmes /
ne he ne falleth in-to perils / þᵗat perils escheweth /
And al be so / þᵗat it seme / þᵗat thow art in siker place; yet shaltow alwey do thy diligence / in kepyng of thy persone /
this is to seyn / ne be nat necligent to kepe thy persone / nat oonly fro thy grettest enemys / but fro thy leeste enemy
¶ Senek seith ▽ A man þᵗat is wel auysed / he dredeth his leste enemy ▽
Ouyde seith ▽ that the litel wesele / wol slee the grete Bole / ⁊ the wilde hert
¶ And the book seith / a litel thorn may prikke a kyng ful soore / And an hound / wol holde the wilde boor ▽
But nathelees / I sey nat/ thow shalt be so coward / þᵗat thow doute / ther / wher as is no drede ▽

The book seith / that som folk haue gret lust to deceyue / but yet they dreden hem / to be de
ceyued /
yet shaltow drede / to been empoysoned / ⁊ kepe thee / from the compaignye of scorneres /
¶ For the book seith / with Scorneres / make no compaignye / but flee hire wordes / as venym
¶ Now as to the seconde point where as youre wise conseilours / conseiled yow / to warnestore youre hous with gret diligence;/
I wolde fayn knowe / how þᵗat ye vnderstonde thilke wordes / ⁊ what is youre sentence

¶ Melibeus answerde ⁊ seyde ▽ Certes / I vnder
stonde it in this wise / that I shal warnestore myn hous / with toures / swiche as han Castelles / ⁊ othere manere edifices / ⁊ armure / ⁊ Artelries /
by whiche thynges / I may my persone ⁊ myn hous / so kepen ⁊ defenden / þᵗat myne enemys shul been in drede / myn hous for to approche

¶ To thys sentence / answerde anon Prudence ▽ Warnestoryng quod she of heighe toures / ⁊ of grete edifices / with grete costages / ⁊ with gret tᵃrauaille / and whan þᵗat they been accompliced / yet be they nat worth a stree / but if they been defended / by trewe freendes / that been oolde / and wise
¶ And vnderstonde wel / þᵗat the gretteste / and the strengeste garnysoūn / þᵗat ryche man may haue / as wel / to kepen his persone / as his goodes; is
þᵗat he be biloued with his subgetz and with his neighebores

¶ For thus seith Tullius / that ther is a manere garneson / þᵗat no man may venquyse ne discomfite / and þᵗat
is /
a lord / to be biloued / of his Citezeins / and of his peple
¶ Now sire / as to the .iij.e poynt wher as youre olde and wise conseilours / seiden / þᵗat yow ne oghte nat sodeynly / ne hastily / proceden in this nede /
but þᵗat yow oghte pʳurueien and apparailen yow in this cas / with greet diligence and greet deliberacioūn;
trewely / I trowe þᵗat they seyden right wisely / and right sooth
¶ For Tullius seith ▽ In euery nede / er thow bigynne it apparayle thee / with greet diligence ▽
thanne seye I / þᵗat in vengeance takynge / in werre / in bataile / and in warnestorynge /
er thow bigynne / I rede þᵗat thow apparaile thee ther-to / and do it with greet deliberacioūn
¶ For Tullius seith / that long apparailynge biforn the bataile / maketh short victorie ▽
And Cassidorus seith / the garneson is strenger / whan it is long tyme auysed
¶ But now lat vs speke of the conseil þᵗat was acorded by youre neighebores swiche as doon yow reuerence / with-outen loue /

youre olde enemys recon
siled / youre flaterers /

þᵗat conseileden yow cer
teyne thynges pryuely / and openly conseileden yow the contᵃrarie ▽
The yonge folk also / þᵗat conseileden yow / to venge yow / and make werre anoon;
And certes sire / as I haue seyd biforn ▽ ye han greetly erred / to han clepid swich maner folk/ to youre conseil /
whiche conseilours been ynow repreued bi the resons foreseyd /
but nathelees / lat vs now descende to the special ¶ Ye shuln first ꝓproceden after the doctryne of Tullius ▽
Certes / the trouthe of this matere / or of this conseil / nedeth nat/ diligently enquere /
for it is wel wist whiche they been / that han doon to yow / this trespas and vileynye /
and how manye trespasours / and in what manere / they han to yow doon al this wrong and al this vileynye
¶ And after this / thanne shulle ye examyne the .ij.e condicioūn / which þᵗat the same Tullius addeth in this matere /
for Tullius put a thyng/ which þᵗat he clepeth consentynge / this is to seyn /
who been they and whiche been they / and how manye þᵗat consenten to thy conseil in thy wilfulnesse / to do hastif vengeance /
And lat vs considere also / who been they and how manye been they / and whiche been they / þᵗat consenteden / to youre Aduersaries

¶ And certes / as to the firste poynt it is wel knowen whiche folk been they / þᵗat consenteden / to youre hastif wilful
nesse /
for trewely alle tho / þᵗat conseileden yow to maken sodeyn werre / ne been nat youre freendes ▽
Lat vs now considere whiche been they þᵗat ye holde so greetly youre freendes / as to youre persone /

for al be it so / þᵗat ye be myghty and ryche; certes / ye ne been / but
allone /
for certes / ye ne han no child but a doghter /
ne ye ne han bretheren / ne cosyns germayns / ne noon oother ney kynrede /
wherfore / þᵗat youre enemys / for drede sholden stynte / to plede with yow / or destroye youre persone
¶ Ye knowe also / þᵗat youre richesses / moten be despended in diuerse parties /
and whan þᵗat euery wight hath his part they ne wollen take but litel reward / to venge thy deeth ▽
but thyne enemys / been .iij.e and they han manye children /bretheren / cosyns / and oother ney kynrede /
and thogh so were / thow haddest slayn of hem .ij.o or .iij.e yet dwellen ther ynowe / to wreken hir deeth / and to sle thy persone ▽
and thogh so be / þᵗat youre kynrede be moore syker and stedefast than the kyn of youre aduersarie; /
yet nathelees / youre kynrede / nys but a fer kynrede / they been / but litel syb to yow /
and the kyn of youre enemys / been ney syb to hēm / and certes as in that hir condicion / is bet than youres
¶ Thanne / lat vs considere also / if the conseilynge / of hem þᵗat conseileden yow to taken sodeyn vengeance / wheither it acorde to reson;
And certes / ye knowe wel nay;
for as by right and reson / ther may no man take vengeance on no wight but the Iuge þᵗat hath the Iurisdiccioūn of it

whan it is ygraunted hym to take thilke vengeance hastily / or at
temprely / as the lawe requereth
¶ And yet more ouer / of thilke word / that Tullius clepith / consentynge;
thow shalt considere / if thy myght and thy power may consente and suffise / to thy wilfulnesse and to thy conseilours /
And certes / thow mayst wel seyn / that nay /
for sikerly as for to speke ꝓproprely / we may do no thyng but oonly swich thyng as we may do rightfully /
and certes / rightfully ne mowe ye take no vengeance / as of youre ꝓpropre auctoritee /
thanne mowe ye seen / that youre power ne consenteth nat/ ne acordeth nat with youre wilfulnesse
¶ Lat vs now examyne the .iij.e poynt that Tullius clepith Consequent ▽

Thow shalt vnderstande / that the vengeance þᵗat thow purposest for to taken / is the conse
quent
and ther-of folweth another vengeance / peril / and werre / and othere damages with-oute nombre / of whiche / we been nat waar / as at this tyme

¶ And as touchynge the .iiij.e poynt that Tullius clepith en
gendrynge /
thow shalt considere / that this wrong which that is doon to thee / is engendred / of the hate of thyne enemys /

and of the vengeance takynge vp-on that wolde engendre another vengeance / and muchil sorwe / and wastynge of richesses /
as I seyde

¶ Now sire / as touchynge to the poynt that Tul
lius clepith causes / which þᵗat is the laste poynt;
thow shalt vnderstonde / þᵗat the wrong þᵗat thow hast receyued / hath certeyne causes /
whiche þᵗat clerkes clepen Oriens and Efficiens / and Causa longinqua / and causa pꝓpropinqua / this is to seyn; the fer cause / and the ny cause /
the fer cause / is almyghty god that is cause of alle thynges ▽
the neer cause / is thy thre enemys /
the cause accidental / was hate /
the cause material / been the .v. woūndes of thy doghter /
the cause formal / is the manere of hir werkynge / that broghten laddres and clomben In at thy wyndowes /
the cause final / was for to sle thy doghter / it lettyd nat / in as muche as was in hem was ▽
but for to speke of the fer cause; as to what ende they shul come /; or what shal finally bityde of hem in this cas; ne kan I nat deme / but by coniectynge and by supposynge /
for we shuln suppose / that they shul come to a wikked ende /
by cause / þᵗat the book of decrees seith ¶ Selden / or with greet peyne been causes ybroght to good ende / whan they been baddely bigonne
¶ Now sire / if men wolden axe me / why þᵗat god suffrede men to do yow this vileynye; certes I kan nat wel answere / as for no soothfastnesse ▽
for the Apostle seith / that the sciences and the Iugementz of oure lord god almyghty / been ful depe /
ther may no man cōmprehende ne serchen hem suffisantly
¶ Nathelees / by certeyne presumpcions and coniectynges / I holde ⁊ bileue /
that god / which þᵗat is ful of Iustice and of rightwisnesse / hath suffred this bityde / by Iuste cause resonable
¶ Thy name is Melibe / this is to seyn / a man that drynketh hony /

thow hast y-dronke so muchil hony / of swete temporel richesses and delices and hon
ours of this world /
that thow art dronken / and hast forgeten IhūIhesu cⁱrist thy creatour /
thow ne hast nat doon to hym / swich honour and reuerence as thee oghte;
ne thow ne hast nat wel taken kepe / to the wordes of Ouyde ▽ that seith /
vnder the hony of the goodes of thy body; is hyd the venym / that sleth the soule
¶ And Salomon seith ▽ If thow hast founden hony / ete of it that suffiseth /
for if thow ete of it out of mesure; thow shalt spewe / and be nedy and poore /
and perauenture / Crist hath thee in despit and hath torned awey fro thee his face / and his erys of misericorde /

and also he hath suffred / þᵗat thow
hast been punysshed in the manere þᵗat thow hast ytrespased;
¶ Thow hast doon synne agayn oure lord Crist ▽

for certes / the .iij.e enemys of man
kynde / that is to seyn / the flessh / the feend / and the world /
thow hast suffred hem / entre in to thyn herte wilfully / by the wyndowes of thy body /
and hast nat defendid thy self / suffisantly agayns hir assautes ⁊ hir temptacions / so þᵗat they han woundid thy soule. in .v. places ▽
this is to seyn / the dedly synnes / þᵗat been entred in to thyn herte by thy .v. wittes ▽
And in the same manere / oure lord Crist hath wold ⁊ suffred / þᵗat thy .iij.e enemys been entred in to thyn hous by the wyndowes /
and han ywoundid thy doghter in the forseyde manere

¶ Certes quod Melibe / I se wel / þᵗat ye en
force yow muchil by wordes to ouercome me in swich a manere / þᵗat I shal nat venge me of myne enemys /
shewynge me the perils ⁊ the yueles / þᵗat myghten falle of this vengeance ▽
But who so wolde considere in alle vengeances / the perils and yueles þᵗat myghten sewe of vengeance takynge;
a man wolde neuere take vengeance / and that were harm /

for by the venge
ance takynge / been the wikked men disseuered / fro the goode men /

and they þᵗat han wil to do wikked
nesse / restreyne hir wikked purpos / whan they seen the punysshynge ⁊ chastisynge of trespassours ▽
And yet seye I moore / that right as a singuler persone synneth / in takynge vengeance of another man;
right so synneth the Iuge / if he do no vengeance of hem that it han disserued ▽
For Senek seith thus ▽ That maister he seith is good / þᵗat preueth shrewes ▽
And as Cassidore seith ▽ A man dredeth to do outrages / whan he woot ⁊ knoweth / þᵗat it displeseth / to the Iuges and the souereyns ▽
And another seith ▽ The Iuge þᵗat dredeth to do right maketh men shrewes ▽
And Seint Poul thapostle seith in his epistle whan he writeth vn-to the Romayns / That the Iuges beren nat the spere / with-outen cause /
but they beren it to punysshe the shrewes ⁊ mysdoers / ⁊ for to defende the goode men
¶ If ye wol thanne take vengeance of youre enemys; ye shul retourne / or haue youre recours to the Iuge þᵗat hath the Iurisdiccioūn vp-on hem /
⁊ he shal punysshe hem / as the lawe axeth ⁊ requereth
¶ A quod Melibe / this vengeance liketh me no thyng

I bithenke me now ⁊ take hede / how fortune hath norisshed me / fro
my childhode / ⁊ hath holpen me / to passe many a strong paas;
Now wol I assayen hire / trowynge with goddes helpe þᵗat she shal helpe me / my shame for to venge /
¶ Certes quod Prudence / if ye wol werke by my conseil; ye shul nat assayen fortune / by no wey /
ne ye shul nat lene / or bowe vn-to hire / after the word of Senek ▽
for thynges þᵗat been folily doon / ⁊ þᵗat been in hope of fortune; shullen neuere / come to good ende /
And as the same Senek seith ▽ The moore cleer ⁊ the moore shynynge þᵗat fortune is /; the moore brotil ⁊ the sonner broke she is /
trusteth nat in hire / for she nys nat stedefast ne stable /
for whan thow trowest to be moost seur or syker of hir helpe / she wol faile thee ⁊ deceyue thee
¶ And where as ye seyn / that fortune hath norisshed yow fro youre childhode;
I seye / þᵗat in so muchil / shul ye the lasse truste in hire ⁊ in hir wit ▽
For Senek seith ▽ What man þᵗat is norisshed by fortune; she maketh hym to greet a fool /
¶ Now thanne syn ye desire / ⁊ axe vengeance / ⁊ the vengeance / þᵗat is doon after the lawe / ⁊ bifore the Iuge / ne liketh yow nat/

⁊ the vengeance / þᵗat is doon in hope of fortune / is peril
ous ⁊ vncerteyn;
thanne haue ye noon oother remedie / but for to haue youre recours / vn-to the souereyn Iuge / þᵗat vengeth / alle vileynyes ⁊ wronges /
and he shal venge yow / after that hym self witnesseth / where as he seith ▽
leueth the vengeance to me / and I shal do it
¶ Melibe answerde ▽ If I ne venge me nat of the vileynye / þᵗat men han doon to me;
I. somne / or warne hem / þᵗat han doon to me that vileynye / ⁊ alle othere / to do me another vileynye /

for it is writen / If thow take no vengeance of an old vileynye; thou som
nest thyne Aduersaries / to do thee a newe vileynye ▽

And also / for my suffrance / men wolden do me so muchil vileynye / þᵗat I myghte neither bere it ne sus
tene /
and so sholde I been put ⁊ holden ouer lowe ▽
For men seyn / I muchil suffrynge / shul manye thynges falle vn-to thee / whiche yow shalt nat mowe suffre
¶ Certes quod Prudence / I gᵃraunte yow / þᵗat ouer muchil suffrance / is nat good /
but yet ne folweth it nat ther of / þᵗat euery persone / to whom men don vileynye / take of it vengeance /

for that aper
teneth ⁊ longeth al oonly to the Iuges / for they shul venge the vileynyes ⁊ iniuries /
and therfore / tho two auctoritees / þᵗat ye han seyd aboue / been oonly / vnderstonden in the Iuges;
for whan they suffren ouer muchil / the wronges ⁊ vileynyes to be doon with-outen punysshynge;
they somne nat a man al oonly / for to do newe wronges / but they comanden it

¶ Also / a wys man seith / That the Iuge / þᵗat cor
recteth nat the Synnere; comandeth ⁊ biddeth hym do synne ▽
And the Iuges ⁊ souereyns / myghten in hir land so muchil suffre of the shrewes ⁊ mysdoerys /
þᵗat they sholden by swich suffrance by pꝓproces of tyme / wexen of swich power ⁊ myght þᵗat they sholden putte out the Iuges ⁊ the souereyns / from hir places /
⁊ at the laste / maken hem lese hir lordshipes
¶ But lat vs now putte / þᵗat ye haue leue to venge yow /
I seye / ye be nat of myght ⁊ power / as now to venge yow /
for if ye wol maken comparison / vn-to the myght of youre Aduersaries; ye shul fynde in manye thynges þᵗat I haue shewid yow er this; þᵗat hir condicioūn / is bettre than youres /
and therfore seye I / þᵗat it is good as now / þᵗat ye suffre ⁊ be pacient
¶ Forther-moore / ye knowen wel / that after the cōmune sawe; it is a woodnesse / a man to stryue with a strenger / or a moore myghty man / than he is hym self /
⁊ for to stryue / with a man / of euene strengthe / that is to seyn / with as strong a man as he is; it is peril /
and for to stryue with a wayker man / it is folye ▽
and therfore / sholde a man fle stryuynge / as muchil as he myghte ▽
For Salomon seith ▽ It is a greet worshipe to a man / to kepen hym fro noyse ⁊ stryf ▽
And if it so bifalle / or happe / þᵗat a man of gretter myght ⁊ strengthe / than thow art do thee greuance;
Studie ⁊ bisie thee rather / to stille the same greuance / than for to venge thee ▽
For Senek seith / That he putteth hym in greet peril / þᵗat stryueth with a gretter man / than he is hym self ▽
And Catoūn seith ▽ If a man / of hyer estaat or degree / or moore myghty than thow / do thee anoy / or greuance; suffre hym /
for he þᵗat ones hath greued thee / may another tyme / releue thee ⁊ helpe;
¶ Yet sette I cas / ye haue bothe myght ⁊ licence for to venge yow;
I seye / þᵗat ther be ful manye thynges / þᵗat shul restreyne yow / of vengeance takynge /
⁊ make yow / for to enclyne to suffre ⁊ for to han pacience / in the wronges / þᵗat han been doon to yow
¶ First ⁊ foreward / If ye wol considere the defautes / þᵗat been in youre owene persone;
for whiche defautes / god hath suffred yow haue this tribulacioūn / as I haue seyd yow / her biforn ▽

For the Poete seith / That we oghten paciently taken / the tribu
lacions þᵗat comen to vs / whan þᵗat we thynken ⁊ consideren / þᵗat we han disserued to haue hem ▽

And
Seint Gregorie seith / That whan a man / considereth wel / the nombre of his defautes and of his synnes;
the peynes ⁊ the tribulacioūns þᵗat he suffreth / semen the lesse vn-to hym /

And in as muche as hym thynk
eth / his synnes / moore heuy ⁊ greuous;
in so muche / semeth his peyne the lighter and the esier vn; to hym
¶ Also / ye owen / to enclyne ⁊ bowe youre herte / to take the pacience / of oure lord IhūIhesu crist. as seith Seint Peter / in hise Epistles ▽
IhūIhesu crist he seith / hath suffred for vs / ⁊ yeuen ensample to euery man / to folwe ⁊ sewe hym /
for he dide neuere synne / ne neuere cam ther a vileynous word / out of his mouth /
Whan men cursed hym / he cursed hem noght And whan men betten hym / he manaced hem noght
¶ Also / the grete pacience / which Seintes / þᵗat been in Paradys / han had / in tribulacions þᵗat they han y-suffred / with-outen hir desert or gilt
oghte muchil stire yow to pacience
¶ Forther moore / ye sholde enforce yow to haue pacience /
considerynge / þᵗat the tribulacions of this world / but litel while endure / ⁊ soone passed been ⁊ goon /
And the ioye þᵗat a man seketh to haue by pacience in tribulacioūns; is perdurable / after that the Apostle seith / in his Epistle /
The ioye of god he seith / is perdurable / that is to seyn / euere lastynge
¶ Also / troweth ⁊ bileueth stedefastly / þᵗat he nys noght wel ynorisshed ne wel ytaught þᵗat kan nat haue pacience / or wol nat receyue pacience ▽
For Salomon seith ▽ That the doctrine ⁊ the wit of a man / is knowen by pacience ▽
And in another place he seith / That he þᵗat is pacient gouerneth hym by greet prudence ▽
And the same Salomon seith ▽ The angry ⁊ wrathful man / maketh noyses / And the pacient man / attempreth hem ⁊ stilleth ▽
he seith also ▽ It is moore worth to be pacient than for to be right strong
And he þᵗat may haue the lordshipe of his owene herte; is moore to preyse / than he þᵗat by his force / or strengthe / taketh grete Citees ▽
And ther-fore / seith Seint Iame in his Epistle / That pacience / is a greet vertu of perfeccioūn
¶ Certes quod Melibe / I graunte yow / Dame Prudence / þᵗat Pacience / is a greet vertu of perfeccioūn /
but euery man / may nat haue the perfeccioūn / þᵗat ye seken /

ne I nam nat of the nōmbre / of right par
fite men /
for myn herte / may neuere be in pees / vn-to the tyme / it be vengid ▽
And al be it so / þᵗat it was greet peril to myne enemys / to do me a vileynye / in takynge vengeance vp-on me;
yet token they noon hede of the peril / but fulfilden / hir wikked wyl ⁊ hir corage ▽
And therfore me thynketh / men oghtēn nat repreue me / thogh I putte me in a litel peril / for to venge me /
⁊ thogh I do a greet excesse / that is to seyn / þᵗat I venge / oon outᵃrage by another //
A. quod dame Prudence / ye seyn youre wil ⁊ as yow liketh ▽
But in no caas of the world / a man sholde nat do outᵃrage ne excesse / for to vengen hym ▽
For Cassidore seith ▽ That as yuele / dooth he þᵗat vengeth hym by outrage / as he / þᵗat dooth the outrage ▽
And ther-fore / ye shul venge yow / after the ordre of right ▽ that is to seyn / by the lawe / and nat by excesse / ne by outᵃrage ▽
And also / if ye wol venge yow / of the outᵃrage of youre Aduersaries in oother manere than right comandeth; ye synnen ▽
And therfore seith Senek▽ That a man shal neuere venge / shrewednesse / by shrewednesse /
And if ye seye / þᵗat right axeth a man / to defende violence by violence / and fightynge by fightynge;
Certes / ye seye sooth / whan the defense / is doon anon / with-outen interualle / or with-outen taryynge / or delay /
for to defenden hym / ⁊ nat for to vengen hym ▽
And it bihoueth / þᵗat a man putte swich attemperance in his defense /
þᵗat men / haue no cause / ne matere / to repreuen hym þᵗat defendeth hym / of excesse ⁊ outrage ▽
Pardee ye knowe wel / þᵗat ye maken no defense as now / for to defende yow / but for to venge yow /
and so seweth it þᵗat ye han no wyl / to do youre dede attemprely /
and therfore / me thynketh / that pacience is good ▽ For Salomon seith ▽ That he / þᵗat is nat pacient shal haue greet harm /
¶ Certes quod Melibe / .I. graunte yow / þᵗat whan a man / is inpacient ⁊ wrooth / of that þᵗat toucheth hym nat and þᵗat aperteneth nat vn-to hym / thogh it harme hym / it is no wonder ▽
For the lawe seith / That he is coupable / þᵗat entremetteth hym / or medleth / with swich thyng as apertenet nat vn-to hym
¶ And Salamōn seith That he þᵗat entremeteth of the noyse / or stryf / of another man; is lyk to hym / þᵗat taketh an hound by the erys /
for right as he / that taketh a straunge hound by the erys / is outher while / biten with the hound;
right in the same wise is it resoūn / þᵗat he haue harm þᵗat by hys inpacience medleth hym / of the noyse / of another man / where / as it aperteneth nat vn-to hym ▽

But ye knowe wel þᵗat this dede / that is to seyn / my grief and my desese
toucheth me right ny /

And therfore / thogh I be wrooth / and in
pacient it is no meruaille /
and sauynge youre gᵃrace / I kan nat se / þᵗat it myghte greetly harme me / thogh I tooke vengeance /
for I am richere ⁊ moore myghty / than myne enemys been /

and wel knowen ye / þᵗat by moneye ⁊ by hauynge grete posses
sions / been alle the thynges of this world gouerned ▽
And Salomon seith ▽ That alle thynges obeyen to moneye

¶ Whanne Prudence / hadde herd hir housbonde auanten hym / of his richesse ⁊ of his moneye; dispreis
ynge / the power of his Aduersaries; she spak ⁊ seyde in this wise ▽
Certes deere sire / I graunte yow / þᵗat ye been / riche ⁊ myghty /
⁊ þᵗat the richesses been goode / to hem / þᵗat han wel ygeten hem / ⁊ þᵗat wel konne vsen hem ▽
For right as the body of a man / may nat lyue with-oute the soule; namoore may it lyue / with-oute the temporel goodes /

and by rich
esses / may a man gete hym grete ▽
¶ And therfore / seith Pamphilles ▽ If Anetherdes doghter / he seith / be riche; she may chese / of a thousand men / which she wol take to hir housbonde ▽
for of a thousand men; oon wol nat forsaken hire / ne refusen hire ▽
And this Pamphilles seith also ▽ If thow be right happy / that is to seyn / If thow be right riche; thow shalt fynde / a greet nombre of felawes ⁊ freendes /

and if thy fortune chaunge / that thow wexe poore; far
wel freendshipe ⁊ felaweshipe /
for thow shalt been / al allone / with-outen any compaignye / but if it be / the compaignye of poore folk
¶ And yet seith this Pamphilles moore ouer ▽ That they þᵗat been / thralle ⁊ bonde of lynage / shuln be maad / worthy and noble by the richesses /
and right so as by richesses / ther comen manye goodes; right so by pouerte / come ther manye harmes ⁊ yueles ▽

for greet pouerte / con
streyneth a man / to do manye yueles ▽

And ther
fore clepeth Cassidore / pouerte / the moder of Ruyne /
that is to seyn / the moder of ouerthrowynge / or fallynge down
¶ And therfore / seiþ Piers Alfonce ▽ Oon of the gretteste Aduersitees of this world / is /
whan a free man by kynde / or of burthe / is constreyned by pouerte / to eten / the almesse of his enemy ▽
And the same seith Innocent in oon of his bookes ▽ he seith / That sorweful ⁊ myshappy / is the condicioūn of a poore beggere /
for if he axe nat his mete; he dyeth for hungir /
And if he axe / he dyeth for shame / and algates necessitee constreyneþ hym to axe ▽
And therfore seith Salomon ▽ That bettre is to dye / than for to haue swich pouerte ▽

And as the same Salo
mon seith / Bettre it is / to dye of bitter deeth / than for to lyuen in swich wise
¶ By thise resons / þᵗat I haue seyd vn-to yow / and by manye othere resons / þᵗat I koude seye /
I graunte yow / þᵗat richesses been goode / to hem þᵗat geten hem wel / and to hem / þᵗat wel vsen tho richesses ▽
And ther-fore wol I shewe yow / how ye shul haue yow / and how ye shul bere yow in gaderynge of richesses / and in what manere ye shul vsen hem
¶ First ye shul geten hem / with-outen greet desir by good leiser sekyngly and nat ouer hastily;
For a man þᵗat is to desirynge to geten richesses / abandoneth hym first to thefte / ⁊ to alle othere yueles ▽
And therfore seith Salomon ▽ he þᵗat hasteth hym to bisily to wexe riche / shal be noon Innocent ▽
He seith also / that the richesse / þᵗat hastily cometh to a man; soone ⁊ lightly gooth and passeth from a man ▽
But that richesse þᵗat cometh litel ⁊ litel / wexeth alwey ⁊ multiplieth ▽
And sire / ye shullen gete richesses by youre wit ⁊ by youre tᵃrauaille vn-to youre pꝓprofit /
and that with-outen wrong or harm doynge / to any oother persone ▽
For the lawe seith ▽ that ther maketh no man hym self riche; if he do harm / to another wight ▽
this is to seyn / that nature defendeth ⁊ forbedeth by right þᵗat no man make hym self riche / vn-to the harm of another persone
¶ And Tullius seith / that no sorwe / ne no drede of deeth / ne no thyng þᵗat may falle vn-to a man /
is so muchel ageyns nature / as a man / to encresse his owene profit to the harm of another man;
And thogh the grete men and the myghty men geten richesses. moore lightly than thow;

yet shaltow nat be ydel ne slow / to do thy ꝓprofit for thow shalt in alle wise / fle ydel
nesse ▽
For Salomon seith ▽ that ydelnesse techeth a man to do manye yueles ▽
And the same Salomon seith / that he þᵗat tᵃrauaileth ⁊ bisieþ hym / to tilien his lond; shal ete breed /
but þᵗat is ydel and casteth hym to no bisynesse ne ocupacioūn / shal falle in-to pouerte and dye for hunger /
And he þᵗat is ydel ⁊ slow; kan neuere fynde couenable tyme / for to do his pꝓprofit ▽
For ther is a versifiour seith ▽ that the ydel man excuseth hym in wynter / by cause of the grete coold / and in somer / by encheson of the hete ▽

For thise causes seith Caton ▽ waketh / and enclineth yow nat ouer mychel / for to slepe ▽ for ouer mychel
reste / norissheth and causeth manye vices ▽
And therfore / seith Seint Ierome ¶ Dooth sōmme goode dedes / þᵗat the deuel / which is oure enemy / ne fynde yow nat vnocupied /

for the deuel / ne takeþ nat lightly / vn-to his werk
ynge / swiche as he fyndeth ocupied in goode werkes
¶ Thanne thus / In getynge richesses / ye mosten fle ydelnesse /
and afterward ye shul vse the richesses whiche ye haue geten / by youre wit and by youre tᵃrauaille /
in swich a manere / þᵗat men holde yow nat to scars / ne to sparynge / ne to fool large / that is to seyn / ouer large a Spendere ▽
For right as men blamen an Auarous man / by cause of his scarsitee ⁊ chyncherie;
in the same wise is he to blame / þᵗat spendeth ouer largely /
and therfore seith Catoūn ▽ Vse he seith thy richesses / þᵗat thow hast ygeten /
in swich a manere / þᵗat men haue no matere ne cause / to calle thee / neither wrecche ne chynche /
for it is greet shame to a man / to haue a poore herte and a riche purs ▽
He seith also / the goodes þᵗat thow hast ygeten / vse hem by mesure / that is to seyn / spende mesurably /
for they / þᵗat folily wasten and despenden / the goodes þᵗat they han;
whan they han namoore ꝓpropre of hir owene; they shapen hem / to take the goodes of another man ▽
I seye thanne / that ye shal fle Auarice /
vsynge youre richesses in swich manere / þᵗat men seye nat/ þᵗat youre richesses been ybiryed /
but þᵗat ye haue hem in youre myght and in youre weldynge ▽
For a wys man / repreueth the Auaricious man ⁊ seith thus / in two vers ▽
Wher-to and why / biryeth a man his goodes by his grete Auarice / and knoweth wel / þᵗat nedes moste he dye;
for deeth / is the ende of euery man / as in this present lyf /
And for what cause / or encheson ioyneth he hym / or knytteth he hym / so faste vn-to his goodes /
þᵗat alle hise wittes / mowen nat disseueren hym / or departen hym fro hise goodes /
and knoweth wel / or oghte knowe / þᵗat whan he is deed / he shal no thyng bere with hym out of this world ▽
And ther-fore / seith Seint Austyn ▽ That the Auaricious man / is likned vn-to helle /
þᵗat the moore it swolweth / the moore desir it hath to swolwe ⁊ deuoure /
And as wel / as ye wolde eschewe to be called an Auaricious man or chynche;
as wel sholde ye kepe yow ⁊ gouerne yow in swich a wise / þᵗat men calle yow nat fool large ▽
Ther-fore seith Tullius ▽ The goodes he seith of thyn hous / sholde nat been hidde ne kept so cloos; but þᵗat they myghte been opned by pitee ⁊ debonairetee /

that is to seyn;
to yeue hem part þᵗat han greet nede /
ne thy goodes sholden nat be so open / to be euery mannes goodes
¶ Afterward / in getyng of youre richesses / and in vsynge hem; ye shul alwey / haue thre thynges in youre herte ▽
that is to seyn / oure lord god / Conscience / and good name
¶ First ye shul haue god in youre herte /
and for no richesse / ye shullen do no thyng which may in any manere displese god / that is youre Creatour ⁊ makere ▽
For after the word of Salomon / It is bettre to haue a litel good / with the loue of god /;
than to haue mychel good ⁊ tresor / and lese the loue of his lord god ▽
And the ꝓprophete seith; That bettre it is to been a good man / ⁊ haue a litel good / and tresor /;
than to be holden a shrewe / ⁊ haue grete richesses ▽
And yet seye I ferther moore / that ye sholden alwey doon youre bisynesse / to gete yow richesses /
so þᵗat ye gete hem / with good conscience ▽
And thapostle seith / that ther nys thyng in this world / of which / we sholden haue so greet ioye / as whan oure conscience / bereth vs good witnesse ▽
And the wise man seith ▽ The substance of a man / is ful good / whan synne is nat in mannes conscience
¶ Afterward / in getynge of youre richesses / ⁊ in vsynge of hem;
yow moste haue greet bisynesse ⁊ greet diligence / þᵗat youre goode name / be alwey kept ⁊ conserued ▽

For Salo
mon seith ▽ that bettre it is ⁊ moore it auaileth a man / to haue good name / than for to haue grete richesses /
And therfore / he seith in another place ▽ do greet diligence seith Salomon in kepynge of thy freend / and of thy goode name /
for it shal lenger abyde with thee / than any tresor / be it neuer so precious ▽
And certes / he sholde nat be called a gentil man / that after god ⁊ good conscience / alle thynges left ne dooth his diligence ⁊ bisynesse / to kepen his goode name ▽
And Cassidore seith / that it is signe of a gentil herte / whan a man / loueth ⁊ desireth / to haue a good name ▽
And therfore seith seint Austyn ▽ that ther been two thynges / þᵗat arn necessarie ⁊ nedefulle /
and that is good conscience / ⁊ good loos ▽
that is to seyn / good conscience / to thyn owene persone inward / and good loos for thy neighebore outward ▽
And he / þᵗat trusteth hym so muchil in his goode conscience /
þᵗat he displeseth / and setteth at noght his goode name or loos / and rekketh noght thogh he kepe nat hys goode name; nys but a cruwel cherl

¶ Sire / now haue I shewed yow / how ye shul do / in getynge richesses / ⁊ how
ye shullen vsen hem /
And I se wel / þᵗat for the trust þᵗat ye han in youre richesses / ye wol moeue werre ⁊ bataille /·

I conseile yow / þᵗat ye bigynne no werre / in trust of youre richesses for they ne suffisen noght werres to mayn
tene /
And therfore seith a Philosophre / That man þᵗat desireth / and wole algates han werre; shal neuere haue suffisance /

for the richer þᵗat he is; the gretter despenses moste he make / if he wol haue wor
shipe ⁊ victorie ▽
And Salomon seith / That the gretter richesses þᵗat a man hath / the mo despendours he hath ▽
And deere sire / al be it so / þᵗat for youre richesses / ye mowe haue muchel folk;
yet bihoueth it nat ne it is nat good / to bigynne werre / where as ye mowe / in oother manere haue pees vn-to youre worshipe ⁊ ꝓprofit ▽
for the victorie of batailles þᵗat been in this world / lyth nat in greet nombre / or multitude of peple / ne in the vertu of man /
but it lyth in the wyl / ⁊ in the hand / of oure lord god almyghty /
and ther-fore Iudas Machabeus / which was goddes knyght
yet he reconforted his litel compaignye / and seyde / right in this wise ▽
Als lightly quod he / may oure lord god almyghty / yeue victorie to fewe folk as to manye folk/
for the victorie of a bataile cometh nat by the grete nombre of peple /
but it come / fro oure lord god of heuene ▽
And deere sire / for as muchel as ther is no man certeyn / if it be worthy / þᵗat god yeue hym victorie / or naght after that Salomon seith;
therfore euery man / sholde greetly drede / werres to bigynne ▽
And by cause þᵗat in batailles / fallen manye perils /
⁊ happeth outher while / þᵗat as soone is the grete man slayn / as the litel man /
And as it is ywriten / in the seconde book of kynges ▽ The dedes of batailles / been Auenturouse ⁊ no thyng certeyne /
for as lightly / is oon hurt with a spere / as another
¶ And for ther is greet peril in werre; therfore sholde a man / fle ⁊ eschewe werre / in as muchel / as a man may goodly ▽
For Salomon seith / he þᵗat loueth peril / shal falle in peril
¶ After þᵗat dame Prudence / hadde spoken in this manere / Melibe answerde ⁊ seyde

¶ I se wel dame Prudence that by youre faire wordes ⁊ by youre resons / þᵗat ye han shewed me; þᵗat the werre / liketh yow no
thyng

but I haue nat yet herd youre con
seil / how I shal do in this nede
¶ Certes quod she / I conseile yow / þᵗat ye acorde with youre Aduersaries / ⁊ þᵗat ye / haue pees with hem ▽
For Seint Iame seith / in hise epistles / That by concord ⁊ pees / the smale richesses / wexen grete /
⁊ by debaat and discord / the grete richesses fallen doun /
And ye knowen wel / þᵗat oon of the gretteste ⁊ moost souereyn thyng þᵗat is in this world / is vnitee ⁊ pees /
And therfore seyde oure lord IhūIhesu crist to hise Apostles / in this wise ▽
Wel happy ⁊ blessed been they / þᵗat louen / ⁊ pʳurchacen pees / for they been called children of god
¶ A quod Melibe now se I wel / þᵗat ye louen nat myn honur ne my worshipe ▽
Ye knowen wel / þᵗat myne Aduersaries han bigonnen this debaat and brige by hire outᵃrage /
⁊ ye se wel / þᵗat they ne requeren ne preyen me nat of pees / ne they asken nat to be reconsiled;
wol ye thanne / þᵗat I go meke me ⁊ obeye me to hem ⁊ crye hem mercy;
for sothe / that were nat my worshipe ▽
For right as men seyn / þᵗat ouer greet homlynesse / engendreth despisynge; so fareth it by to greet humylitee / or mekenesse /

¶ Thanne bigan dame Prudence / to maken sem
blant of wrathe ⁊ seyde ▽
Certes sire / sauf youre grᵃrace / I loue youre honur ⁊ youre ꝓprofit/ as I do myn owene / ⁊ euere haue doon /
ne ye / ne noon oother / syen neuere the contᵃrarie ▽
And yet if I hadde seyd / þᵗat ye sholde han pʳurchaced the pees ⁊ the reconsiliacioūn; I ne hadde nat muchel mystake me / ne seyd amys ▽
For the wise man seith ▽ The dissensioūn / bigynneth by another man / ⁊ the reconsilyng bigynneth by thy self ▽
And the ꝓprophete seiþ / Flee shrewednesse / ⁊ do goodnesse /
seke pees ⁊ folwe it as muchel as in thee is ▽
yet seye I nat þᵗat ye shul rather pʳursue to youre Aduersaries for pees / than they shuln to yow; /
for .I. knowe wel / þᵗat ye been so hard herted / þᵗat ye wol do / no thyng for me ▽
And Salomon seith / That he þᵗat hath ouer hard an herte / atte laste / he shal myshappe ⁊ mystyde
¶ Whanne Melibe hadde herd dame Prudence / make semblant of wrathe / he seyde in this wise ▽
Dame / I pray yow / þᵗat ye be nat displesed / of thynges þᵗat I seye /
for ye knowe wel / þᵗat I am angry ⁊ wrooth / ⁊ that is no wonder /
and they þᵗat been wrothe / witen nat wel what they doon / ne what they seyn ▽
Therfore / the ꝓprophete seith / That troubled eyen / han no cleer sighte /
but seieth ⁊ conseileth me / as yow liketh / for I am redy / to do / right as ye wol desire /

⁊ if ye repreue me of my folie; I am the moore holden
to loue yow / ⁊ to preise yow ▽
For Salomon seith ▽ That he þᵗat repreueth hym þᵗat dooth folie;
he shal fynde gretter gᵃrace / than he þᵗat deceyueth hym by swete wordes
¶ Thanne seyde dame Prudence / I make no semblant of wrathe ne of angir / but for youre grete ꝓprofit ▽

For Salomon seith ▽ he is moore worth / þᵗat re
preueth / or chideth a fool / for his folie / shewynge hym semblant of wrathe;
than he þᵗat supporteth hym ⁊ preiseth hym / in his mysdoynge / ⁊ laugheth at his folie ▽
And this same Salomon seith afterward ▽ That by the sorweful visage of a man / that is to seyn / by the sory ⁊ heuy contenance of a man;
the fool correcteþ ⁊ amendeth hym self

¶ Thanne seyde Melibe / I shal nat konne an
swere / vn-to so manye resons / as ye putten to me ⁊ shewen /

seieth shortly / youre wil ⁊ youre con
seil / ⁊ I am al redy / to fulfille ⁊ perfourne it
¶ Thanne / dame Prudence / discouered al hir wyl vn-to hym / ⁊ seyde ▽
I conseile yow quod she / abouen alle thynges / þᵗat ye make pees bitwene god ⁊ yow /
⁊ beth reconsiled vn-to hym ⁊ to his gᵃrace /
for as I haue seyd yow heer biforn; god hath suffred yow / to haue this tribulacioūn ⁊ disese / for youre synnes /
and if ye do / as I seye yow / god wol sende youre Aduersaries vn-to yow /

⁊ maken hem falle at youre feet redy to do youre wyl ⁊ youre com
andementz ▽

For Salomon seith / whan the con
dicion of man / is plesant ⁊ likynge to god;

he changeth the hertes of the mannes Aduersaries / ⁊ con
streyneth hem / to biseken hym of pees ⁊ of gᵃrace /

and I pray yow / lat me speken with youre Aduer
saries / in pryuee place /
for they shal nat knowe / þᵗat it be of youre wyl / or youre assent.
and thanne / whan I knowe hir wyl ⁊ hir entente; I may conseille yow / the moore seurly
¶ Dame quod Melibe / dooth youre wyl / ⁊ youre likynge /
for I putte me hoolly / in youre disposicion ⁊ ordinance
¶ Thanne dame Prudence / whan she say the goode wyl of hir housbonde; she delyueride / ⁊ took auys in hir self /
thynkynge / how she myghte brynge this nede / vn-to a good conclusioūn ⁊ to a good ende;
And whan she saugh hir tyme / she sente for thise Aduersaries to come vn-to hire / in to a pⁱriuee place /
⁊ shewed wysly vn-to hem / the grete goodes / þᵗat comen of pees /
⁊ the grete harmes ⁊ perils / þᵗat been in werre /

⁊ seyde to hem / in a goodly manere; / how þᵗat hem oghten haue greet re
pentance /
of the Iniurie ⁊ wrong þᵗat they hadden doon / to Melibe hir lord / ⁊ vn-to hire / ⁊ to hir doghter //
And whan they herden / the goodliche wordes / of dame Prudence;

they weren so supprised ⁊ rauysshed / ⁊ hadden so
greet ioye of hire / þᵗat wonder was to telle ▽
A lady quod they / ye han shewid vn-to us / the blessynge of swetnesse / after the sawe of Dauid the ꝓprophete ▽
For the reconsilynge / which we ne been nat worthy to haue in no manere /
but we oghten requeren it with greet contricioūn ⁊ humylitee;
ye of youre grete goodnesse / haue presented vn-to vs ▽
Now se we wel / þᵗat the science / ⁊ the konnynge of Salomon / is ful trewe /
for he seith / That swete wordes / multiplien ⁊ encressen freendes / ⁊ maken shrewes / to be debonaire ⁊ meke
Certes quod they / we putten oure dede ⁊ al oure matere / ⁊ cause / al hoolly / in youre goode wyl /

⁊ been redy to obeye vn-to the speche ⁊ comande
ment of my lord Melibe ▽
And therfore deere ⁊ benygne lady / we preyen yow / ⁊ biseken yow / as mekely / as we konne ⁊ mowen /

þᵗat it like / vn-to youre grete goodnesse / to ful-fille in dede / youre good
liche wordes /
for we consideren ⁊ knowelichen / þᵗat we han offendid ⁊ greued / my lord Melibe / out of mesure /
so ferforth / þᵗat we been nat of power / to maken his amendes ▽
⁊ ther-fore / we oblige ⁊ bynde vs ⁊ oure freendes / for to do al his wyl ⁊ his comandementz ▽
but perauenture / he hath swich heuynesse ⁊ swich wrathe to vsward / by cause of oure offense /
þᵗat he wole enioyne vs / swich peyne / as we mowe nat bere / ne sustene ▽
And ther-fore noble lady / we biseken to youre wommanly pitee /
to taken swich auisement in this nede / þᵗat we ne oure freendes / be nat desherited ⁊ destroyed / thurgh oure folie
¶ Certes quod Prudence / it is an hard thyng ⁊ right perilous /
þᵗat a man putte hym al outrely in the arbitracioūn ⁊ Iuggement/ and in the myght ⁊ power of hise enemys ▽
For Salomon seith; leeueth me / ⁊ yeueth credence / to that þᵗat I shal seyn ¶ I seye quod he / ye peple / ⁊ gouernours / ⁊ gouernours of holy chirche /
to thy sone / to thy wyf / to thy freend / ne to thy brother /
ne yeue thow neuere myght ne maistrie of thy body / whil yow lyuest ▽
Now / sithen he defendeth / þᵗat man sholde nat yeue to his brother / ne to his freend / the myght of his body;
by a strenger reson / he defendeth ⁊ forbedeth a man / to yeue hym self to his enemy /

And nathe
lees I conseille yow / þᵗat ye mystruste nat my lord /
for I woot wel ⁊ knowe verraily / þᵗat he is debonaire ⁊ meke / large / curteys /
⁊ no thyng desirous / ne coueitous / of good / ne richesse /
for ther nys no thyng in this world þᵗat he desireth / saue oonly / worshipe ⁊ honour
¶ Forther moore I knowe wel ⁊ am right seur / þᵗat he shal no thyng do in this nede / with-outen my conseil /

and I shal so werken in this
cause / þᵗat by the gᵃrace of oure lord god / ye shul be reconsiled vn-to vs
¶ Thanne seyden they with o voys ▽ Worshipful lady / we putten vs ⁊ oure goodes al fully / in youre wyl ⁊ disposicioūn /
⁊ been redy to come / what day þᵗat it like vn-to youre noblesse / to lymyte vs / or assigne vs /
for to maken / oure obligacion ⁊ boond / as strong as it liketh vn-to youre goodnesse /
þᵗat we mowe fulfille / the wyl of yow / ⁊ of my lord Melibe

¶ Whanne Dame Prudence / hadde herd the an
sweres of thise men; she bad hēm go agayn pⁱriuely /
⁊ she retourned / to hir lord Melibe / ⁊ tolde hym / how she fand hise Aduersaries ful repentant
knowelichynge ful lowely / hir synnes ⁊ trespas / ⁊ how they weren redy / to suffren al peyne /
requerynge ⁊ prayynge hym / of mercy ⁊ pitee
¶ Thanne seyde Melibe ▽ he is wel worthy / to haue pardoūn ⁊ foryifnesse of his synne / þᵗat excuseth nat his synne /
but knowelicheth ⁊ repenteth hym / axinge Indulgence ▽
For Senek seith ▽ There is the remissioūn ⁊ foryifnesse / where as the confessioūn is /
for confessioūn / is neighebore to Innocence ▽
And he seith / in another place that hath shame of his synne ⁊ knowelicheth it ▽ And ther-fore / I assente ⁊ conferme me to haue pees;
but it is good / þᵗat we do it nat with-outen thassent ⁊ wil of oure freendes
¶ Thanne was Prudence / right glad ⁊ ioyeful / ⁊ seyde ▽
Certes sire quod she / ye han wel ⁊ goodly answerd /
for right as by the conseil / assent/ ⁊ help / of youre frendes / ye han ben stired / to venge yow / ⁊ make werre;

right so / with
outen hire conseil / shul ye nat acorde yow / ne haue pees with youre Aduersaries ▽
For the lawe seith ▽ Ther nys no thyng so good / by wey of kynde / as a thyng to been vnbounde / by hym þᵗat it was ybounde ▽
And thanne Dame Prudence / with-outen delay / or taryynge / sente anon messages / for hir kyn / ⁊ for hire olde freendes / whiche þᵗat were trewe ⁊ wise /
and tolde hem by ordre / in the presence of Melibe / al this matere / as it is aboue expressed ⁊ declared /

⁊ preyde hem / þᵗat they wolde yeuen hire auys ⁊ con
seil / what best were to do / in this nede ▽

And whan Melibees freendes / hadde taken hire auys ⁊ deliber
acioūn of the forseyde matere /
⁊ hadden examyned it by greet bisynesse ⁊ greet diligence;
they yaue ful conseil / for to haue pees ⁊ reste /
⁊ þᵗat Melibe / sholde receyue with good herte / hise Aduersaries / to foryifnesse ⁊ mercy ▽

And whanne Dame Prudence / hadde herd the assent of hir
lord Melibe / ⁊ the conseil of his freendes /
acorde with hire wyl and hire entencioūn;
she was wonderly glad in herte / ⁊ seyde ▽
Ther is an old ꝓprouerbe quod she / seith ▽ that the goodnesse þᵗat thow maist do this day / do it
⁊ abide nat ne delye it nat til tomorwe /
And therfore I conseille / þᵗat ye sende youre messages / swiche as been discrete ⁊ wise
vn-to youre Aduersaries / tellynge hēm on youre bihalue /
þᵗat if they wol trete of pees ⁊ of acord /
þᵗat they shape hem / with-outen delay or taryynge / to come vn-to vs /
which thyng ꝑparfoʳurned was in dede /
and whanne thise trespassours ⁊ repentynge folk of hir folies / that is to seyn / the Aduersaries of Melibe /
hadden herd / what thise messagers seyden vn-to hem;
they weren right glad ⁊ ioyeful / ⁊ answereden ful mekely ⁊ benygnely /
yeldynge gᵃraces ⁊ thankynges / to hire lord Melibe ⁊ to al his compaignye /
⁊ shopen hem with-oute delay to go with the messagers / ⁊ obeye to the comandement of hire lord Melibe /
And right anon they tooken hire wey / to the court of Melibe /
⁊ tooke with hem somme of hir trewe freendes / to make feith for hem / ⁊ for to been hire borwes ▽
And whan they were come / to the presence of Melibe; he seyde hem thise wordes
¶ It standeth thus quod Melibe ⁊ sooth it is / þᵗat ye
causelees ⁊ with-outen skile ⁊ resoūn /
han doon grete Iniuries ⁊ wronges to me / ⁊ to my wyf Prudence / ⁊ to my doghter also /
for ye han entred in-to myn hous by violence /
⁊ haue doon swich outᵃrage / þᵗat alle men knowen wel / þᵗat ye han deserued the deeth ▽
And therfore wol I knowe ⁊ wite of yow /
wheither ye wol putte the punysshynge ⁊ chastisynge / ⁊ the vengeance of this outᵃrage / in the wil of me / ⁊ of my wyf or ye wol nat
¶ Thanne the wiseste of hem thre / answerde for hem alle / ⁊ seyde ▽
Sire quod he / we knowen wel / þᵗat we been vnworthy / to comen vn-to the court of so greet a lord ⁊ so worthy / as ye been /
for we han so gretly mystaken vs / ⁊ han offendid ⁊ gilt in swich a wise / ageyn youre hey lordshipe /
þᵗat trewely / we han deserued the deeth /
but yet for the grete goodnesse ⁊ debonairetee / þᵗat al the world / witnesseth of youre persone /;
we submitten vs / to the excellence ⁊ benygnytee of youre gᵃracious lordshipe /
⁊ ben redy tobeye / to alle youre comandementz /
bisekynge yow / þᵗat of youre merciable pitee / ye wol considere oure grete repentance ⁊ lowe submissioūn /
⁊ gᵃraunten vs foryeuenesse / of oure outᵃrageous trespas ⁊ offense /

for wel we knowen / þᵗat youre liberal gᵃrace ⁊ mercy / strecchen ferther / in-to good
nesse / than
doon oure outᵃrageouse giltes ⁊ trespas in-to wikkednesse /

al be it þᵗat cursedly ⁊ damp
nablely / we han agilt ageyn youre hey lordshipe
¶ Thanne Melibe / took hem vp fro the ground ful benygnely /
⁊ receyued hir obligacioūns ⁊ hir bondes by hir othes / vp-on hir plegges ⁊ borwes /
⁊ assigned hem a certeyn day / to retourne vn-to his court
for to accepte ⁊ receyue / the sentence ⁊ Iugement þᵗat Melibe wolde comande / to be doon on hem / by the causes aforeseyd ▽
whiche thynges ordeyned; euery man retoʳurned to his hous ▽
And whanne þᵗat dame Prudence saugh hir tyme / she feyned / ⁊ axed hir lord Melibe /
what vengeance he thoghte to taken of hise Aduersaries;
¶ To which / Melibe answerde ⁊ seyde ▽ Certes quod he .I. thynke ⁊ purpose me fully /

to dis
herite hem / of al þᵗat euere they han / and for to putte hem in exil / for euere
¶ Certes quod Dame Prudence / this were a cruel sentence / ⁊ muchel ageyn reson /
for ye been riche ynow ⁊ han no nede of oother mennes good /
⁊ ye myghten lightly in this wise / geten yow a coueitous name /
which is a vicious thyng ⁊ oghte been eschewid of euery man /
for after the sawe of the word of thapostle ▽ Coueitise / is roote of alle harmes /
And therfore / it were bettre for yow / to lese so mychel good of youre owene / than for to take of hire good / in this manere /

for bettre it is / to lese good with wor
shipe / than it is / to wynne good with vileynye ⁊ shame /

And euery man / oghte do his diligence ⁊ his bisy
nesse / to geten hym a good name /
and yet shal he nat oonly bisien hym in kepynge his goode name;
but he shal also / enforcen hym alwey / to do som thyng by which he may renouelle his goode name ▽

For it is writen / That the olde goode loos / or good name of a man / is soone goon ⁊ passed / whanne it is nat newed / ne re
noueled ▽
⁊ as touchynge þᵗat ye seyn / ye wol exile youre Aduersaries;
that thynketh me / muchel agayn resoūn / ⁊ out of mesure /

con
sidered the power / þᵗat they han yeuen yow vp-on hem self ▽
And it is writen / that he is worthy to lesen his pⁱriuilege / þᵗat mysvseth / the mygh ⁊ the power þᵗat is yeuen him /
And I sette cas / ye myghte enioyne hem that peyne / by right ⁊ by lawe /
which I trowe ye mowe nat do /
I seye / ye myghte nat putte it to execucioūn per auenture /
⁊ thanne were it likly / to retorne to the werre / as it was biforn /

And ther-fore / if ye wole / þᵗat men do yow obeis
ance; yow
moste deme moore curteisly /
this is to seyn / ye moste yeue / moore esy sentences ⁊ Iugementz ▽
For it is writen / that he / þᵗat moost curteisly cōmmandeth / to hym / men moste obeyen /

⁊ ther
fore .I. pray yow / þᵗat in this necessitee / ⁊ in this nede / ye caste yow to ouercome youre herte ▽
For Senek seith ▽ that he þᵗat ouercomeþ his herte; ouercomeþ twies ▽
And Tulliƪus seith ▽ ther is no thyng so cōmmēndable in a greet lord /

as whan he is debon
aire ⁊ meke / ⁊ apeiseth hym lightly ▽
And I pray yow / þᵗat ye wol forbere now to do vengeance
in swich a manere / þᵗat youre good name / may be kept ⁊ conserued /
⁊ þᵗat men mowe / haue cause ⁊ matere / to preise yow / of pitee ⁊ of mercy /
⁊ þᵗat ye haue no cause / to repente yow of thyng þᵗat ye doon ▽
For Senek seith ▽ He ouercometh / in an yuel manere þᵗat repenteth hym / of his victorie ▽

Wher
fore / I prey yow / lat mercy be in youre herte /
to theffect ⁊ entente / þᵗat god almyghty haue merci on yow in his laste Iugement ▽

For Seint Iame seith / in his epistle ▽ Iugement with
oute mercy / shal be doon to hym / þᵗat hath no mercy / of another wight
¶ Whanne Melibe hadde herd / the grete skiles ⁊ resons of dame Prudence / ⁊ hir wise Informacioūns ⁊ techynges /
his herte gan enclyne to the wyl of his wyf/ considerynge hir trewe entente /

con
formed hym anon ⁊ assented fully / to werken after hir conseil /
⁊ thonked god / of whom ꝓprocedeth al vertu / ⁊ al goodnesse / þᵗat hym sente a wyf of so greet discrecioūn ▽

And whanne the day cam / þᵗat hise Ad
uersaries / sholde appieren / in his presence;
he spak to hem ful goodly / ⁊ seyde in this wise ▽
Al be it so / þᵗat of youre pride ⁊ by presumpcioūn ⁊ folie / ⁊ of youre necligence ⁊ vnkonnynge /
ye haue mysborn yow / ⁊ trespased vn-to me;
yet for as muchel / as I se ⁊ biholde youre grete humylitee /
⁊ þᵗat ye been sory ⁊ repentant of youre giltes;
it constreyneth me / to do yow gᵃrace ⁊ mercy /
Wherfore I receyue yow to my gᵃrace /
⁊ foryeue yow outrely alle the offenses / Iniuries ⁊ wronges / þᵗat ye haue doon / ageyns me ⁊ myne /
to this effect ⁊ to this ende / þᵗat god/ of his endelees mercy /
wole atte tyme of oure dyynge / foryeuen vs oure giltes þᵗat we han trespassed to hym / in this wrecched world /
for doutelees / if we be sory ⁊ repentant of the synnes ⁊ giltes / whiche we han trespased / in the sighte of oure lord god;

he is so free ⁊ so merci
able
þᵗat he wole foryeuen vs oure giltes /
⁊ bryngen vs to the blisse / that neuere hath ende.
¶ Here is endid / Chaucers tale / of Melibe.

div.l: ¶ The Prologe / of the Persons tale /.
BY that the Maūnciple hadde his tale al ended
The Sonne / fro the South lyne is descended
So lowe / that he nas nat to my sighte
Degrees .29. as of highte
Ten of the Clokke / it was / so as I gesse
For .xj. foot and litel moore / or lesse
My shadwe was / at thilke tyme as there
Of swich feet/ as my lengthe parted weere
In .6. feet equal / of ꝓproporcioūn
Ther with / the Mones exaltacioūn
I mene Libra / alwey gan ascende
As we were entryng at a Thropes ende
For which oure hoost as he was wont to gye
As in this cas / oure Ioly compaignye
Seyde in this wise / lordynges euerichon
Now lakketh vs / no tales / mo than oon
Fulfild is my Sentence / and my decree
I trowe / þᵗat we han herd of ech degree
Almoost fulfild is al myn ordinaunce
I pray to god / so yeue hym right good chaunce
That telleth this tale / to vs lustily
Sire preest quod he / artow a Vicary
Or arte a person / sey sooth by thy fey
Be what thow be / ne breke thow nat oure pley
For euery man saue thow / hath toold his tale
Vnbokele / and shewe vs / what is in thy Male
For trewely / me thynketh by thy cheere
Thow sholdest/ knette vp wel a greet matere
Telle vs a fable anon / for Cokkes bones
¶ This person / answerde al atones
Thow getest fable noon / ytoold for me
For Poul / that writeth vn to Thymothe
Repreueth hem / þᵗat weyuen Soothfastnesse
And tellen fables / and swich wrecchednesse
Why sholde I sowen draf/ out of my fest
Whan I may sowen whete / if þᵗat me lest
For which I seye / þᵗat if yow list to heere
Moralitee / and vertuous matere
And thanne / þᵗat ye wol yeue me Audience
I wole ful fayn / at Cristes reuerence
Do yow plesance / leueful / as I kan
But trusteth wel / I am a Southren man
I kan nat geste / rom / ram / ruf / by lettre
Ne god woot/ rym holde I but litel bettre
And ther fore if yow lest/ I wol nat glose
I wol yow telle / a myrie tale in prose
To knytte vp al this feste / and make an ende
And Ihesu for his gᵃrace / wit me sende
To shewe yow the wey / in this viage
Of thilke parfit glorious pilgrymage
That highte Ierusalem celestial
And if ye vouche sauf/ anon I shal
Bigynne vp on my tale / for which I preye
Telle youre auys / I kan no bettre seye
But nathelees / this meditacion
I putte it ay / vnder correccioūn
Of clerkes / for I am nat textuel
I take but the sentence / trusteth wel
Ther fore / I make protestacioūn
That I wol stonde / to correccioūn
¶ Vp on this word / we han assented soone
For as it semed / it was for to doone
To enden / in som vꝰertuous sentence
And for to yeue hym / space and audience
And bede oure hoost he sholde to hym seye
That alle we / to telle his tale hym preye
¶ Oure hoost hadde the wordes for vs alle
Sire preest quod he / now faire yow bifalle
Sey what yow list and we wol gladly heere
And with that word / he seyde in this manere
Telleth quod he / youre meditacioūn
But hasteth yow / the sonne wole adoun
Beth fructuous / and that in litel space
And to do wel / god sende yow his grace
¶ Explicit prohemium.

div.ab: ¶ Here bigynneth / the Persons tale.
div.note: Ieremie. 6o. ▽ State suꝑper vias / ⁊ videte ⁊ interrogate de semitis antiquis / que sit via bona / ⁊ ambulate in ea / ⁊ inuenietis refrigeriuūm animabus vestris, c̄etc
div.ab: Ovre swete lord / god of heuene / that no man wole ꝑperisse / but wole þᵗat we comen alle to the knoweliche of hym / and to the blisful lyf / þᵗat is ꝑperdurable /
amonesteth vs / by the ꝓprophete Ieromie / that seith in this wise
Stondeth vp on the weyes / and seeth / and axeth of olde pathes / that is to seyn / of olde sentences / which is the goode wey /
and walketh in that wey / and ye shal fynde refresshynge for youre soules c̄etc
¶ Manye been / the weyes espirituels / that leden folk / to oure lord IhūIhesu crist and to the regne of glorie /
of whiche weyes / ther is a ful noble wey and a ful couenable / which may nat faile / to man ne to womman / þᵗat thurgh synne hath mysgoon / fro the righte wey of Ierusalem celestial /
and this wey / is clepid Penitence / of which / men sholde gladly herknen and enquere wᵗith al his herte /

to wite / what is peni
tence / and whennes / it is clepid penitence / and in how manye maneres / been the accions / or werkynges of penitence/
and how manye spices / ther ben of penitences / and whiche thynges / aꝑpertenen ⁊ bihouen to penitence / whiche thynges / destourben penitence.

¶ Seint Ambrose seith ▽ that penitence / is the pleynynge of man / for the gilt þᵗat he hath doon / and na
moore to doon any thyng for which hym oghte to pleyne

¶ And som doctour seith ▽ Penitence / is þe wayment
ynge of man / þᵗat sorweth for his synne / and pyneth hym self / for he hath mysdoon ▽
Penitence / wᵗith certeyne circumstances / is verray repentance of a man / þᵗat halt hym self in sorwe / ⁊ oother peyne for hise giltes /
and for he shal be verray penitent he shal first biwailen / the synnes / þᵗat he hath doon / and stedefastly pʳurposen in his herte / to haue shrift of mouthe / and to doon satisfaccioūn /

and neuere to doon thyng for which hym oghte moore to biwaile / or to compleyne / and to con
tinue in goode werkes / or ellis / his repentance may nat auayle
For as seith Seint Isydre ▽ He is a Iapere / and a gabbere / and no verray repentant þᵗat eft soone dooth thyng for which hym oghte repente ▽
Wepynge / and nat for to stynte to do synne / may nat auaile ▽

But nathelees men shal hope / þᵗat at euery tyme þᵗat man falleth / be it neuer so ofte / þᵗat he may arise þurgh peni
tence / if he haue gᵃrace / but certeynly / it is greet dowte /
for as seith Seint Gregorie ▽ Vnnethevix ariseth he out of his synne / that is charged / wᵗith the charge of yuel vsage /
and ther fore / repentant folk/ þᵗat stynte for to synne / ⁊ forlete synne / er þᵗat synne forlete hem / holy chirche / halt hem siker of hire sauacion /

and he þᵗat synneth / ⁊ verraily repenteth hym in his laste / holy chirche / yet hopeth his sauacion by the grete mercy of oure lord IhūIhesu crist for his repentance / but taak the sikertene weycertum /
And now / sith þᵗat I haue declared yow / what thyng is penitence / now shul ye vnderstonde / þᵗat ther been .iij. acciouns of penitence /
¶ The firstecciouns of penitence: is / þᵗat if a man be baptised / after þᵗat he hath synned ▽
Seint Augustyn seith / but he be penitent / for his olde synful lyf / he may nat bigynne / the newe clene lyf /
for certes / if he be baptised with oute penitence of his olde gilt / he receyueth the mark of baptesme / but nat the gᵃrace / ne the remissioūn of hise synnes / til he haue repentance verray
¶ Another defaute is this / that men doon deedly synne / after þᵗat they han receyued baptesme /
¶ The thridde defaute is ▽ that men fallen in venyal Synnes after hire baptesme / fro day to day ▽
ther of seith seint Augustyn ▽ That penitence / of goode and of humble folk. is the penitence of euery day.

¶ The [app][orig]speces[/orig][c1]species[/c1][lit]speces [al][i]species[/i][/al][/lit][/app] species of penance / been .iij. ▽ that oon[iij. Sp]eces of penauūnce: of hem / is solempne ▽ Another is cōmmune ▽ and the thridde is priuee

¶ Thilke penaūnce þᵗat is so
lempne / is in two maneres / as to be put out of holy chirche in lente / for slaughtre of children / and swich manere thyng

¶ Another is / whan man hath synned openly / of which synne / the fame is openly spoken in the contree / and thanne holy chirche / by Iuge
ment destreyneth hym / for to doon open penance ▽
Cōmmune penaūnce is / that preestes enioynen men cōmmunly / in certeyn cas / as for to goon ꝑperauenture naked in pilgrymage / or barefoot
¶ Pryuee penaūnce / is thilke þᵗat men doon al day for pⁱriuee synnes / of whiche / we shryue vs pryuely and receyue pryuee penance
¶ Now shaltow vnderstande / what bihoueth bihoueth to penitence and is necessarie to verray ꝑperfit penitence / and this stant/ on .iij. thynges ▽

Contricioūn of herte ▽ Con
fessioūn of Mouth / and Satisfaccioūn ▽

for which / seith seint Iohn Crisostomƪus
¶ Penitence destreyneth man / to accepte benygnely euery peyne / þᵗat hym is enioyned / with contricioūn of herte / ⁊ shrift of Mowthe / wᵗith satis
faccioūn / and in wirkynge of alle manere humylitee /
And this is fruytful penitence agayn .iij. thynges / in whiche we wrathe oure lord IhūIhesu crist ▽
this is to seyn / by delit in thynkynge / by recchelesnesse in spekynge / by wikked synful wirkynge /
And agayns thise / wikkede giltes is penitence / that may be likned vn to a tree /
¶ The roote of this tree is contricioūn / þᵗat hideth hym in the herte of hym / þᵗat is verray repentant right as the roote of a tree hideth hym in the erthe ▽
Of the roote of Contriciov spryngeth a stalke þᵗat bereth branches / and leues of confession / and fruyt of satisfaccion ▽

for which / crist seith in his gospel ▽ Dooth digne fruyt of penitence / for by this fruyt may men knowe this tree / and nat by the roote / that is hyd / in the herte of man / ne by the branches / ne the leues of Confession ▽
And therfore / oure lord IhūIhesu crist seith thus ▽ by the fruyt of hem / shul ye knowe hem ▽
Of this roote eek spryngeth a seed of gᵃrace / the which Seed / is moder of Sikernesse / and this Seed / is egre and hoot ▽

the grace of thys Seed / spryngeth of god thurgh re
membrance on the day of dome / ⁊ on the peynes of helle ▽
Of this matere / seith Salomon ▽ that in the drede of god / man forleteth his synne ▽
the hete of thys seed / is the loue of god / ⁊ the desirynge of the Ioye ꝑperdurable /
this hete / draweth the herte of man to god ⁊ dooth hym hate his synne /

for soothly / ther is no thyng þᵗat sauoureth so wel to a child / as the mylk of his norice / ne no thyng is to hym moore ab
homynable / than thilke mylk/ whan it is medled wᵗith oother mete ▽
right so the synful man / þᵗat loueth his synne / hym semeth / it is to hym moost swete of any thyng ▽
but fro þᵗat tyme / þᵗat he loueth sadly oure lord IhūIhesu crist/ ⁊ desireth the lyf ꝑperdurable / ther nys to hym / no thyng moore abhomynable /
for soothly / the lawe of god / is the loue of god ▽ for which / Dauid the ꝓprophete seith ¶ I haue loued thy lawe ⁊ hated wikkednesse ⁊ hate / he þᵗat loueth god/kepeth his lawe ⁊ his word;

this tree saugh the ꝓprophete D{*}aniel in spirit vp on the auysion of Nabugodonosor / whanne he con
seiled hym / to do penitence;
Penance / is the tree of lyf / to hem þᵗat it receyuen / ⁊ he þᵗat holdeth hym in verray penitence / is blessed / after the sentence of Salomon

¶ In this penitence or Contricioūn / man shal vn
derstonde iiij. thynges / that is to seyn / what is Contricioūn / and whiche ben the causes / þᵗat moeuen a man to Con
tricioūn / and how he
sholde be contrit/ and what Con
tricioūn auaileth to the soule ▽
thanne it is thus /. that Contricioūn is the verray sorwe / þᵗat a man receyueth in his herte for hise synnes / wᵗith sad purpos to shryue hym ⁊ to do penance ⁊ neuere moore to do synne /
and this sorwe / shal ben in this manere / as seith Seint Bernard ▽ It shal ben heuy and greuous ⁊ ful sharpe ⁊ poynaūnt in herte ▽
first/ for man hath agilt his lord ⁊ his Creatour / and moore sharp ⁊ poynaūnt for he hath agilt his fader celestial /

and yet moore sharpe ⁊ poynaūnt/ for he hath wrathed ⁊ agilt hym þᵗat boughte hym / þᵗat wᵗith his precious blood / hath delyuered vs fro the bondes of synne / ⁊ fro the creweltee of the deuel / ⁊ fro the peynes of helle

¶ The causes / þᵗat oghten moeuen a man to Con
tricioūnauses to meue a n to contricioun / been .vj. / First/ a man shal remembren hym of hise synnes /

but looke þᵗat thilke remem
brance.I. ▽ ne be to hym no delit by no wey / but gret shame ⁊ sorwe for his gilt ▽ for Iob seith / Synful men / doon werkes worthy of Confessioūn /
And therfore / seith Ezechie ▽ .I. wol remembre me alle the yeris of my lyf / in bitternesse of myn herte ▽
And god seith in the Apocalipes / Remembre yow / fro whennes þᵗat ye ben falle / for biforn that tyme þᵗat ye synned / ye were the children of god / and lymes of the regne of god /
but for youre synne / ye ben woxe / thral ⁊ foul and membres of the feend / hate of Aungeles / Sclaundre of holy chirche / ⁊ foode of the false serpent ꝑperpetuel matere / of the fyr of helle /

And yet moore foul and abhom
ynable for ye trespasen so ofte tyme / as dooth the hound / þᵗat retorneth to ete his spewyng
⁊ yet be ye fouler / for youre longe contynuynge in synne and youre synful vsage / for which / ye been roten in youre synne as a beest in his donge /
Swiche manere of thoughtes / maken a man haue shame of his synne ⁊ no delit as god seyth by the ꝓprophete Ezechiel /
ye shal remembre yow of youre weyes / and they shullen displese yow soothly / Synnes been the weyes þᵗat leden folk to helle
¶ The seconde cause / þᵗat oghte make a man.2. to han desdeyn of synne / is this / that as seith Seint Peter ▽ who so þᵗat dooth synne / is thral of synne / ⁊ synne put a man in greet thraldam /

And ther
fore / seith the prophete Ezechiel / I wente sorweful / in desdayn of my self; ¶ Certes wel oghte a man / haue desdayn of synne ⁊ with drawe hym fro that thraldom ⁊ vileynye ▽

And lo / what seith Seneca in this matere / he seith thus / though I wiste þᵗat god / neither god ne man / ne sholde neuere knowe it/ yet
wolde I. haue desdayn / for to do synne
¶ And the same Seneca also seith ▽ .I. am born to gretter thynges / than to be thral to my body / or than for to maken / of my body a thral /
ne a fouler thral may no man ne wōmman make of his body / than for to yeue his body to synne /
al were it the fouleste cherl / or the fouleste wōmman þᵗat lyueth and leest of value / yet is he thanne moore foul ⁊ moore in seruitute /

euere fro the hyer degree þᵗat man falleth / the moore is he thral and moore to god ⁊ to the world vil ⁊ abhomyn
able

¶ O goode god / wel oghte man haue greet des
dayn of synne / sith þᵗat thurgh synne / ther he was fre / now is he maked bonde /
And ther fore / seith Seint Augustyn ¶ If thow hast desdayn of thy seruant if he agilte or synne; haue thow thanne desdayn / þᵗat thow thy self sholdest do synne /
take reward of thy value / þᵗat thow ne be to foul to thy self ▽
Allas / wel oghten they thanne haue desdayn / to ben seruauntz ⁊ thralles to synne / ⁊ soore ben ashamed of hem self/
þᵗat god of his endelees goodnesse / hath set hem in heigh estat or yeuen hem wit strengthe of body / heele / beautee / ꝓprosꝑperitee /
and boghte hem fro the deeth wᵗith his herte blood; þᵗat they so vnkyndely agayns his gentilesse / quyten hym so vileynsly to slawghtre of hir owene soules

¶ Onota de pulcritudine Mu
lierum malarum] goode god / ye wommen // þᵗat been of so greet beautee / remembreth yow / of the ꝓprouerbe of Salomon ▽ he seith /
likneth a fair womman þᵗat is a fool of hire body / lyk to a ryng of gold / þᵗat were in the groyn of a Sowe /
for right as a Sowe wroteth in euerich ordure; so wroteth she hire beaute in stynkynge ordure of synne
¶ The thridde cause / þᵗat oughte moeue a man.3. to Contricion / is drede of the day of dome / and of the horrible peynes of helle /
For as Seint Ierome seith / At euery tyme / þᵗat me remembreth of the day of dome / I quake /
for whan I ete and drynke / or what so þᵗat I do / euere semeth me / þᵗat the trompe sowneth in myn ere /
Riseth ye vp þᵗat ben dede ⁊ cometh to the Iugement
¶ O goode god / muchel oghte a man to drede swich a Iugement/ ther as we shullen ben alle / as seith Seint Poul / biforn the Sete / of oure lord IhūIhesu crist/

where as he shal maken / a general con
gregacioūn / where / as no man may ben absent
for certes / there ne auaileth noon essoyne / ne excusacioūn /
and nat oonly / þᵗat oure defautes shullen be Iuged / but eek þᵗat alle oure werkes / shullen openly be knowe /

And as þᵗat seith Seint
Bernard / ther ne shal no pletynge auaile / ne no sleighte ¶ we shullen yeue rekenynge of euerich ydel word /
there shul we han a Iuge / þᵗat may nat ben deceyued / ne corrupt. and why; for certes / alle oure thoghtes / ben descouered as to hym / ne for prayere / ne for mede / he wol nat ben corrupt
and therfore seith Salomon ▽ the wrathe of god . . . . . no gap in the MS. ne wol nat spare no wight/ for prayere / ne for yifte / And therfore / at the day of dome / ther nys noon hope to escape ▽
Wherfore / as seith Seint Anselme ▽ Ful gret anguisse / shullen the synful folk haue / at that tyme /

ther shal the stierne ⁊ wrothe Iuge / sitte aboue / and vnder hym / the horrible pit of helle open to de
stroye hym þᵗat moot biknowen hise synnes / whiche synnes / openly ben shewed biforn god / and biforn euery creature /
and on the left syde / mo deueles than herte may bithynke / for to harye and drawe the synful soules / to the pyne of helle /
and wᵗith Inne the hertes of folk/ shal be the bityng conscience / ⁊ with oute forth / shal be the world al brennynge /
Whider shal thanne / the wrechched synful man fle to hyde hym / certes / he may nat hyde hym / he moste come forth and shewe hym ▽
for certes / as seith Seint Ierome / the erthe shal caste hym / out of hym / and the See also / ⁊ the Eyr also / þᵗat shal ben / ful of thonder clappes ⁊ lightnynges ▽
Now soothly / who so wel remembreth hym of thise thynges / I gesse that his synne shal nat torne hym in delit/ but to gret sorwe / for drede of the peyne of helle ▽

And ther
fore / seith Iob to god ▽ Suffre lord / þᵗat I may awhile biwayle / ⁊ wepe er I go / wᵗith oute returnynge to the dirke lond / couered / with the derknesse of deeth /
to the lond of mysese ⁊ of derknesse / where as is the shadwe of deeth / where as ther is / noon ordre / or ordinaūnce / but grisly drede þᵗat euere shal laste
¶ Lo here may ye seen / þᵗat Iob preyde respit awhile / to biwepe and wayle his trespas / for soothly / o day of respit/ is bettre than al the tresor of this world /

And for as muche / as a man may acquyte hym self biforn god by penitence in this world / and nat by tresor // therfore sholde he preye to god / to yeue hym respit awhile / to biwepe ⁊ biwaylen his trespas /
for certes / al the sorwe þᵗat a man myghte make fro the bigynnyng of the world / nys but a litel thyng at regard of the sorwe of helle
¶ The cause / why þᵗat Iob clepeth helle / the lond of derknesse;

vnderstondeth
that he clepeth it lond / or erthe / for it is stable ⁊ neuere shal faile / dirk. for he þᵗat is in helle / hath defaute of light material /
for certes the derke light þᵗat shal come out of the fyr þᵗat euere shal brenne / shal turne hym al to peyne / þᵗat is in helle / for it sheweth hym / to the horrible deueles / þᵗat hym tormenten /
couered wᵗith the derknesse of deeth ▽ that is to seyn / þᵗat he þᵗat is in helle shal haue defaute of the sighte of god / for certes the sighte of god / is the lyf ꝑperdurable ▽

The derk
nesse of deeth / ben the synnes þᵗat the wrecched man hath doon / whiche þᵗat destourben hym / to se the face of god / right as a dirk clowde bitwixe vs and the sonne
¶ Lond of myseise / by cause þᵗat ther ben .iij. manere of defautes agayns .iij. thynges / þᵗat folk of this world han in this present lyf ▽ that is to seyn /. honours /. delices /. and rychesses ▽
Agayns honoʳur / han they in helle / shame ⁊ confusion

for wel ye woot þᵗat men clepen honour / the reuerence / þᵗat man dooth to man / but in helle / is noon honoʳur ne reuerence / for certes / namoore reuerence / shal be doon to a kyng than to a knaue ▽
for which / god seith / by the ꝓprophete Ieremye ▽ thilke folk þᵗat me despisen / shulle ben in despit

¶ Honoʳur is eek clepid greet lord
shipe / ther shal no wight seruen oother / but of harm and torment ▽ Honour is eek clepid / greet dignytee ⁊ heigh
nesse / but in helle shul they ben al fortroden of deueles ▽

As god seith ▽ the horrible deueles / shullen goon ⁊ comen vp on the heuedes of dampned folk ▽ And this is / for as muche as the heyere þᵗat they were in this present lyf / the moore shulle they ben abated and defouled in helle
¶ Agayns the richesse of this world / shul they han myseyse of pouerte / and this pouerte shal be in .iiij. thynges /

In defaute of tresor / of which þᵗat dauid seith ▽ the riche folk þᵗat embraceden ⁊ oneden al hir herte to tresor of this world / shulle slepen / in the slepynge of deeth / and no thyng ne shal they fynden in hire handes / of al hire tresor ▽
And moore ouer / the Misayse of helle / shal ben in defaute of mete ⁊ drynke /

for god seith thus by Moyses ▽ they shul ben wasted with honger / and the bryddes of helle / shul deuouren hem / wᵗith bitter deeth / and the galle of the dragon / shal ben hire drynke / and the venym of the dragon / hire morsels ▽
And forther ouer / hire Miseyse / shal ben / in defaute of clothyng for they shullen ben naked in body / as of clothyng saue the fyr / in which they brenne ⁊ othere filthes /

and naked shul they ben of soule / of alle manere vertues / which þᵗat is / the clothyng of soule / where
ben thanne the gaye robes / ⁊ the softe shetes / ⁊ the smale shertes
¶ Lo / what seith god of hem / by the ꝓprophete Ysaye ▽ that vnder hem / shul ben strawed Moththes / ⁊ hire couertures / shullen ben of wormes of helle
¶ And forther ouer / hire myseyse / shal ben in defaute of frendes / for he is nat pouere / þᵗat hath goode frendes / but there is no freend /
