for neither god / ne no creature shal ben freend to hem / and euerich of hem / shal haten oother / wᵗith deedly hate ▽

the sones ⁊ the doghtren / shullen rebellen agayns fader ⁊ moder / and kynrede agayns kynrede / and chiden ⁊ despisen / euerich of hēm oother / bothe day ⁊ nyght ▽ as god seith / by the ꝓprophete Michias
¶ And the louynge children þᵗat whilom loueden so flesshly euerich oother / wolden euerich of heēm eten oother / if they myghte ▽
for how sholde they louen hem togidre / in the peyne of helle /; whan they hateden euerich of hem oother/in the ꝓprosꝑperitee of this lyf /

for truste wel / hire flesshly loue / was dedly hate / as seith the ꝓprophete dauid; who so þᵗat loueth wikked
nesse / he hateth his soule /
and who so hateth his owene soule / certes / he may loue noon oother wight in no manere /

and therfore / in helle is no solas / ne no frendshipe / but euere / the moore flesshly kynredes þᵗat ben in helle / the moore cursynges / the moore chid
ynges / and the moore dedly hate / ther is among hem

¶ And forther ouer / they shul haue defaute / of alle manere delices / for certes / delices ben after the appetites of the .v. wittes / as Sighte /. Herynge /. Smellynge /. Sauor
ynge /. and touchynge/
but in helle/hire sighte/shal be ful of dirknesse ⁊ of smoke; and therfore ful of teerys / and hire herynge / ful of waymentynge and of gryntynge of teeth / as seith IhūIhesu cⁱrist

Hire nose
thirles / shul ben ful of stynkynge stynk ▽ And as seith Ysaye the ꝓprophete ▽ hire sauorynge / shal be ful of bitter galle /
⁊ touchynge of al hir body / ycouered with fyr þᵗat neuere shal quenche / ⁊ with wormes / þᵗat neuere shul dyen / as god seith / by the mowth of Ysaye ▽
And for as muche / as they shul nat wene / þᵗat they may dyen for peyne / and by hire deeth fle fro peyne / that may they vnderstonde in the word of Iob ▽ that seith / there as is the shadwe of deþ /
¶ Certes / a shadwe / hath the liknesse of the thyng / of which it is shadwe / but shadwe / is nat the same thyng of which it is shadwe ▽

right so / fareth the peyne of helle / it is lyk deeth / for the horrible angwissh / and why / for it peyneth
hem euere / as thogh men sholde dye anon / but certes they shal nat dye /
for as seith Seint Gregorie / to wrecche kaityues / shal be deeth with oute deeth / ⁊ ende with outen ende / ⁊ defaute wᵗith oute failynge /
for hire deeth / shal alwey lyuen / ⁊ hire ende shal euere mo bigynne / ⁊ hire defaute / shal nat faile /
And therfore / seith Seint Iohn the Euᵃungelist ▽ they shullen folwe deeth / ⁊ they shal nat fynde hym / ⁊ they shul desiren to dye / and deeth shal fle fro hem ▽
And eek Iob seith / þᵗat in helle / is noon ordre of rewle /

and al be it so / þᵗat god hath creat alle thynges in right ordre / ⁊ no thyng wᵗith outen ordre / but alle thynges / bēn ordeyned ⁊ nom
bred / yet nathelees they þᵗat ben dampned / ben no thyng in ordre / ne holden noon ordre /
for the erthe ne shal bere hem no fruyt ▽
for as the ꝓprophete dauid seith / god shal destroye / the fruyt of the erthe / as fro hem / ne water / ne shal yeue hem no moysture / ne the Eyr no refresshyng ne fyr no light ▽
for as seith Seint Basile ▽ the brennynge of the fyr of this world / shal god yeuen in helle / to hem þᵗat ben dampned /
but the light ⁊ the cleernesse / shal he yeuen in heuene to hise children / right as the goode man / yeueth flessh to hise children / ⁊ bones to hise houndes /
and for they shullen haue noon hope to escape / seith Seint Iob / atte laste / þᵗat ther shal horrour ⁊ grisly drede dwelle with outen ende //
Horrour is alwey drede of harm þᵗat is to come / ⁊ this drede shal euere dwelle in the hertes / of hem þᵗat ben dampned / and therfore; han they lorn al hire hope / for .vij. causes ▽
First for god þᵗat is hir Iuge / shal be wᵗith oute mercy to hem / ne they may nat plese hym / ne noon of hise halwes / ne they ne may yeue no thyng for hire raunsoūn /
ne they haue no Voys / to speke to hym / ne they may nat fle fro peyne / ne they haue no goodnesse in hem that they may shewe / to delyuere hem fro peyne /
And therfore seith Salomon ▽ the wikked man dieþ ⁊ whan he is deed / he shal haue noon hope / to escape fro peyne

¶ Who so thanne wolde wel vn
derstonde thise peynes ⁊ bithynke hym wel / þᵗat he hath disserued thilke peynes for hise synnes / certes he sholde haue moore talent to siken ⁊ to wepe / than for to syngen ⁊ to pleye ▽
for as þᵗat seith Salomon / who so þᵗat hadde the science to knowe the peynes þᵗat ben establised ⁊ ordeyned for synne / he wolde make sorwe /
thilke science / as seith Seint Augustyn / maketh a man / to waymente in his herte /

¶ The .iiije. poynt that
oghte make a manThe .iiij.e mevere to contⁱricioun. haue contricioūn / is the sorweful remembrance of the good / þᵗat he hath left to doon here in erthe / ⁊ eek / the good þᵗat he hath lorn /
Soothly / the goode werkes þᵗat he hath left either they ben the goode werkes þᵗat he wroghte er he fil in to deedly synne / or ellis / the goode werkes þᵗat he wroghte / whil he lay in synne /
Soothly / the goode werkes þᵗat he dide biforn þᵗat he fil in synne / ben al mortefied / ⁊ astoned / ⁊ dulled / by the ofte synnynge /
That othere goode werkes þᵗat he wroghte / whil he lay in dedly synne / they ben outrely dede / as to the lyf / ꝑperdurable in heuene ▽
thanne thilke goode werkes þᵗat ben mortefied by ofte synnyng whiche goode werkes he dide while he was in charitee / ne mowe neuere quyken agayn / wᵗith oute verray penitence /

And ther of seith god / by the mowth of Ezechiel / that if the rightful man re
turne agayn from his rightwisnesse / ⁊ werke wikked
nesse / shal he lyue; /
nay / for alle the goode werkes þᵗat he hath wroght ne shulle neuere ben in remembrance / for he shal dye / in his synne /

and vp on thilke chapitre / seith Seint Gregorie thus ▽ that we shul vnder
stonde this / pⁱrincipally /
that whan we doon dedly synne / it is for nawght thanne to reherse / or drawen in to memorie / the goode werkes þᵗat we han wroght biforn

¶ for certes / in the werkynge of the dedly synne / ther is no trust to no good werk þᵗat we han doon biforn / that is to seyn / as for to haue ther by / the lyf per
durable in heuene /
but nathelees / the goode werkes quyken agayn and comen agayn ⁊ helpen ⁊ auaylen / to haue the lyf ꝑperdurable in heuene / whan we han Contricion /
but soothly the goode werkes þᵗat men doon / whil þᵗat they been in dedly synne / for as muche / as they weren doon in dedly synne / they may neuere quyken agayn /

for certes / thyng þᵗat neuere hadde lyf / may neuere quyken / and natheles / al be it þᵗat they ne auayle noght to han the lyf ꝑperdurable / yet auaylen they / to abreggen of the peyne of helle / or ellis / to gete temporal richesses /
or ellis / þᵗat god wole the rather enlumyne ⁊ lighte / the herte of the synful man to han repentance;
And eek they auailen / for to vsen a man to doon goode werkes / þᵗat the feend / haue the lasse power of his soule /
and thus the curteys lord IhūIhesu crist ne wole þᵗat no good werk be lost for in som what it shal auayle /

but for as muche as the goode werkes / þᵗat men doon whil they ben in good lyf/ ben al amortised by synne folwynge; / and eek sith þᵗat alle the
goode werkes þᵗat men doon / whil they ben in dedly synne / ben outrely dede / as for to han / the lyf ꝑperdurable /
wel may þᵗat man / þᵗat no good werk ne dooth / synge thilke newe frenshe song Iay tout ꝑperdu / mon temps ⁊ mon labour ▽
For certes synne bireueth a man / bothe goodnesse of nature / ⁊ eek the goodnesse of grace /

for soothly / the grace of the holy goost fareth lyk fyr / þᵗat may nat ben ydel / for fyr faileth / anon / as it forleteth his werk
ynge / and right so gᵃrace faileth / anon as it forleteth his werkynge /
thanne leseth the synful man/the goodnesse of glorie / that oonly / is bihight to goode men þᵗat labouren and werken /

Wel may he be sory thanne þᵗat oweth al his lyf to god / as longe as he hath lyued / and eek as longe as he shal lyue / þᵗat no goodnesse ne hath / to paye with his dette to god / to whom he oweth al his lyf /
for truste wel / he shal yeue acountes as seith Seint Bernard / of alle the goodes þᵗat han ben yeuen hym in this present lyf / and how he hath hem despended /
nat so muche / þᵗat ther shal nat ꝑperisse an heer of his heed / ne a moment of an houre ne shal nat perisse of his tyme / þᵗat he ne shal yeue of it a rekenynge
¶ The .v.the thyng þᵗat oghte moeue a man toThe .v.the mevere t contriciouūn Contricion / is remembrance of the passion þᵗat oure lord IhūIhesu crist suffred for oure synnes /

for as seith Seint Bernard / Whil þᵗat I lyue I shal haue remem
brance of the trauailes þᵗat oure lord IhūIhesu crist suffred / in prechynge /

his werynesse in tᵃrauailynge / hise tempt
acions whan he fasted / hise longe wakynges whan he preyed / hise teerys whan þᵗat he weep for pitee of good peple /

the wo / and the shame / ⁊ the filthe þᵗat men seyden to hym / of the foule spittyng þᵗat men spitte on his face / of the buffettes that men yaue hym / of the fowle Mowwes ⁊ of the re
preues þᵗat men to hym seyden /
of the nayles / wᵗith whiche he was nayled to the croys / and of al the remenant of his passioūn / þᵗat he suffred for my synnes / and no thyng for his gilt ▽

And ye shal vnder
stonde / þᵗat in mannes synne / is euery manere ordre of ordinance / turned vp so down /
for it is sooþ þᵗat god /. and reson /. and sensualitee. ⁊ the body of man / ben so ordeyned / þᵗat euerich of thise .iiij. thynges / sholde haue lordshipe ouer that oother /
as thus /. god sholde haue lordshipe ouer resoūn / ⁊ resoūn ouer Sensualitee / ⁊ Sensualitee ouer the body of man /
but soothly / whan man synneth / al this ordre / or ordinance / is turned vp so down /

and therfore
thanne / for as muche as the reson of man / ne wol nat be subget ne obeisaūnt to god / þᵗat is his lord by right /; ther
fore leseth it the lordshipe / þᵗat it sholde haue in Sensualitee / ⁊ eek ouer the body of man /
and why / for Sensualitee rebelleth thanne agayns reson / and by that wey / leseth resoūn the lordshipe ouer Sensualitee ⁊ ouer the body /
for right as reson is rebel to god / right so is bothe sensualitee rebel to reson ⁊ the body also ▽
and certes this desordinaūnce ⁊ this rebellioūn / oure lord IhūIhesu crist aboghte / vp on his precious body ful deere / and herkneth in which wise ▽

for as muche thanne / as reson is rebel to god / ther
fore is man worthy to haue sorwe / and to be deed /

this suffred oure lord IhūIhesu crist for man / after þᵗat he hadde be bitraysed of his disciple and destreyned ⁊ bounde so / þᵗat the blood brast out at euery nayl of hise handes / as seith Seint Augustyn ▽

And forther ouer for as muchel as reson of man ne wol nat daunte sensu
alitee when it may; / therfore / is man worthy to han shame / and this suffrede oure lord IhūIhesu crist for man whan they spette in his visage ▽
and forther ouer / for as muche thanne / as the kaytif body of man / is rebel / bothe to resoūn ⁊ to sensualitee / therfore / it is worthy the deeth /
and this suffred oure lord IhūIhesu cⁱrist for man vp on the croys / where as ther nas no part of his body free wᵗith oute gret peyne ⁊ bitter passioūn /

and al this suffred IhūIhesu crist þᵗat neuere forfeted ▽ . . . . .no gap in the MS. to muchel am I peyned for the thynges þᵗat I neuere deserued and to muche defouled for shendshipe / þᵗat man is worthy to haue ▽

And ther
fore / may the synful man wel seye / as seith Seint Bernard / Acursed be the bitternesse of my synne / for which / ther moste be suffred so muche bitternesse /
for certes after the diuerse discordaūnces of oure wikkednesses / was the passioūn of IhūIhesu crist ordeyned in diuerse thynges ▽

As thus ▽ Certes synful mannes soule is bitraysed of the deuel by coueitise of temporel ꝓprosꝑperitee ⁊ scorned by deceyte / whan he cheseth flesshly delites / and yet is it tormented by inpacience of Aduersitee / and byspet by seruage ⁊ subieccioūn of synne / and atte laste / it is slayn fynally ▽
for this desordenaūnce of synful man / was IhūIhesu crist first bitraysed / and after that was he bownde / þᵗat cam for to vnbynde vs / of Synne ⁊ of peyne ▽
thanne was he biscorned / þᵗat oonly sholde ben honoured in alle thynges of alle thynges /
thanne was his visage þᵗat oghte be desired to be seyn of alle mankynde in which visage Angels desiren to looke / vileynsly bispet /
thanne was he skourged / þᵗat no thyng hadde agilt and fynally / thanne was he crucefied ⁊ slayn ▽

thanne was acompli
ced the word of Ysaie ▽ He was wounded for oure mysdedes / ⁊ defouled by oure felonyes

¶ Now sith þᵗat IhūIhesu crist took vp on hym self the peyne of alle oure wikkednesses; / muchel oghte synful man wepe ⁊ biwayle / þᵗat for hise synnes / goddes sone of heuene / sholde al this peyne endure

¶ The .vj.theThe .vj.the m con thyng þᵗat oghte moeue a man to Contricioūn / is the hope of .iij. thynges / that is to seyn / foryeuenesse of synne / and the yifte of grace wel for to do / and the glorie of heuene / wᵗith which god shal gerdone man for hise goode dedes ▽
And for as muche / as IhūIhesu crist yeueth vs thise yiftes of his largesse ⁊ of his souereyn boūntee / therfore is he clepid Ihus Nazarenus rex Iudeorum

¶ IhūIhesu is for to seyn / Saueour / or Sa
uacioūn / on whom men shal hope / to haue foryifnesse of synnes / which þᵗat is ꝓproprely / Sauacion of synnes /
and therfore / seyde the Aūngel to Ioseph ▽ thow shalt clepe his name Ihus / þᵗat shal saue his peple of hire synnes /
And heerof / seith Seint Peter ▽ ther is noon oother name vnder heuene þᵗat is yeue to any man / by which a man may be saued / but oonly Ihus

¶ Nazarenus / is as muche for to seye / as florissynge / In which a man shal hope / þᵗat he / þᵗat yeueth hym remissioūn of synnes / shal yeue hym eek gᵃrace wel to do / for in the flour/ is hope of fruyt in tyme comynge / and in foryifnesse of synnes / hope of gᵃrace wel to do
¶ I was at the dore of thyn herte seith Ihus / ⁊ clepede for to entre / he þᵗat opneth to me / shal haue foryifnesse of synne /

I wol entre in to hym by my gᵃrace / and sowpe wᵗith hym / by the goode werkes þᵗat he shal doon / whiche werkes / ben the foode of god / and he shal sowpe wᵗith me / by the grete ioye þᵗat I shal yeue hym ▽
thus shal man hope / þᵗat for hise werkes of penance / god shal yeue hym his regne / as he byheteth hym in the gospel.In what manere o ben thy contricioun

¶ Now shal man vnderstonde / in which manere shal ben his contricioūn / I seye / that it shal ben vniuersal and total / this is to seyn / a man shal be verray repentaūnt/ for alle hise synnes þᵗat he hath doon / in delit of his thoght. for delit is ful ꝑperilous /
for ther ben two manere of consentynges / that oon of hem / is clepid / consentynge of affeccion whan a man / is moeued to do synne/and thanne deliteth hym longe / for to thynke on that synne /

and his reson / aꝑperceyueth wel þᵗat it is synne / agayns the lawe of god / and yet his resoūnūn refreyneth nat his fool delit/ or talent though he seeth wel apertly / þᵗat it is agayns the reuerence of god / al though his resoūn / ne consente nat / to doon the
synne in dede /
yet seyn sōmme doctours / þᵗat swich delit þᵗat dwelleþ longe / it is ful ꝑperilous / al be neuer so lite /

and also / a man sholde sorwe / namely / for al that euere he hath desired agayn the lawe of god / with ꝑparfit consentynge of his resoūn / for ther of is no doute / þᵗat it is dedly synne / in the consentynge /
for certes ther is no dedly synne / þᵗat it nas first in mannes thoght ⁊ after that in his delit ⁊ so forth / in to consentynge ⁊ in to dede /
Wherfore I seye / þᵗat many men ne repenten hem neuere of swyche thoghtes ⁊ delites / ne neuere shryuen hem of it but oonly / of the dede of grete synnes outward
¶ Wher fore I seye / þᵗat swiche wikked delites ⁊ wikked thoghtes / ben subtil bigyleris of hem þᵗat shullen ben dampned

¶ Moore ouer / man oghte to sorwen for hise wikked wordes / as wel / as hise wikked dedes / for certes / the repentance of a singuler synne ⁊ nat repente of alle hise othere synnes ▽ or ellis repente hym of alle hise othere synnes / and nat of a synguler synne / may nat auayle /
for certes / god almyghty / is al good / and therfore / outher he foryeueth al / or ellis right noght/
And her of seith Seint Augustyn ¶ I woot certeynly /
þᵗat god is enemy to euerich synnere / And how thanne / he þᵗat obserueth o synne / shal he haue foryeuenesse of the remenant of hise othere synnes; nay;

¶ And forther ouer Contricioūn / sholde be wonder sorweful and ang
uissous / and ther fore / yeueth hym god / pleynly his mercy / and therfore / whan my soule was anguissous wᵗith Inne me / I hadde remembraūnce of god / þᵗat my prayere myghte come to hym

¶ Forther ouer Contⁱricioūn moste be continuel / and þᵗat man haue stede
fast pʳurpos to shryue hym / ⁊ for to amende hym of his lyf /
for soothly / whil Contricion lasteth / man may euere haue hope of foryeuenesse / And of this / cometh hate of synne þᵗat destroyeth synne / bothe in hym self ⁊ eek in othere folk at his power /
for which seith Dauid / ye þᵗat louen god / hateth wikkednesse / for trusteth wel / to loue god / is for to loue that he loueth / nota ⁊ hate that he hateth
¶ The laste thyng þᵗat men shal vnderstonde in Contricioūn / is this / wher of auaileth Contricioūn ¶ I seye / þᵗat som tyme / Contricioūn delyuereth man fro synne /
of which þᵗat Dauid seith ▽ I seye quod Dauid / that is to seyn / I. purposed fermely to shryue me / ⁊ thow lord relessedest my synne /
and right so as Contricioūn auaileth nat / wᵗith outen sad purpos of shrifte / if man haue oportunytee; right so / litel worth is shrifte / or satisfaccion / with oute Contricioūn /

And moore / Contricion destroyeth the prisoūn of helle
and maketh wayk ⁊ feble / the strengthes of the deueles / ⁊ restoreth the yiftes of the holy goost ⁊ of alle goode vertues /

and it clenseth the soule of synne ⁊ delyuereth the soule fro the peyne of helle / ⁊ fro the compaignye of the deuel / and fro the seruage of synne / ⁊ restoreth it to alle goodes espirituels ⁊ to the compaignye cōmmunyoūn of holy chirche /
and forther ouer/ it maketh hym / þᵗat whilom was sone of Ire / to be sone of grace / and alle thise thynges / be preued by holy writ /

and therfore / he þᵗat wolde sette his entente / to thise thynges / he were ful wys / for soothly / he ne sholde nat thanne in al his lyf / haue corage to synne / but yeue his body ⁊ al his herte / to the seruyce of IhūIhesu crist ⁊ ther of doon hym hōmmage /
for certes / oure swete lord IhūIhesu crist hath sparid vs so debonairly in oure folies / þᵗat if he ne hadde pitee of mannes soule / a sory song we myghten alle synge .. . .. . ...
¶ Explicit pⁱrima pars penitencie;
¶ Et incipit secunda pars eiusdem . . .
THe seconde partie of Penitence / is Confessioūn / that is signe of Contricioūn
¶ Now shul ye vnderstonde / what is Confession / ⁊ wheither it oghte nedes be doon / or noon / ⁊ whiche thynges ben couenable to verray Confessioūn
¶ First shaltow vnderstonde / þᵗat Confessioūn is verray shewynge of synnes to the preest
this is to seyn verray / for he moot confesse hym of alle the condicioūns þᵗat bilongen to his synne / as ferforþ as he kan /
al moot be seyd / ⁊ no thyng excused / ne hid / ne forwrapped / ⁊ nat auaūnce hym of hise goode werkes ▽

And forther ouer / it is necessarie to vnder
stonde / whennes þᵗat synnes spryngen / ⁊ how they encressen / ⁊ whiche they ben

¶ Of the spryngynge of Synnes / as seith Seint Paul in this wise ▽ that right as by a man / synne entred first in to this world / and thurgh that synne deth / 'right so thilke deth entred in to alle men þᵗat synneden /
and this man was Adam / by whom synne entred in to this world / whan he brak the comandementz of god /

and therfore / he þᵗat first was so myghty / þᵗat he sholde nat haue deyed / bicam swich oon / þᵗat he moste nedes dye wheither he wolde or noon / ⁊ al his ꝓprogenye þᵗat is in this world/ þᵗat in thilke man synneden

¶ Looke þᵗat in thestat of Innocence / whan Adam ⁊ Eue / naked weren in Paradys
and no thyng ne hadden shame of hir nakednesse /
how þᵗat the serpent þᵗat was moost wily of alle othere bestes þᵗat god hadde maked / seyde to the wōmman ▽ why comanded god to yow / ye sholde nat eten of euery tree in Paradys; ▽

the wōmman answerde / Of the fruyt quod she of the trees in Paradys / we feden vs / but soothly / of the fruyt of the tree þᵗat is in the myddel of Paradys / god forbad vs for to ete / ne nat touche it/ list ꝑper auenture we sholde dyen ▽

the serpent seyde to the wōmman / nay / nay / ye shul nat dyen of deth / for sothe god woot þᵗat what day þᵗat ye eten ther of / youre eyen shulle opne / ⁊ ye shul ben as goddes / konnynge good ⁊ harm ▽

the womman saugh / þᵗat the tree was good to fedynge / and fair to the eyen / ⁊ delitable to sighte / 'she took of the fruyt of the tree ⁊ eet it ⁊ yaf it to hire housbonde / ⁊ he eet ⁊ anon the eyen of hem bothe opnede /
and whan þᵗat they knewe þᵗat they were naked / they sowed of Fyge leues in manere of breches / to hiden hire membres ▽

Here may ye seen / þᵗat dedly synne / hath first suggestioūn of the feend / as sheweth heere by the Naddre / and afterward the delit of the flessh / as sheweth heere by Eua / and after that the consentynge of reson / as sheweth heere by Adam /

For truste wel / thogh so were / þᵗat the feend tempted oon / that is to seyn the flessh / and the flessh hadde delit in the beautee of the fruyt deffended / 'yet certes til þᵗat reson / that is to seyn Adam / con
sented to the etyng of the fruyt yet stood he / in the estat of Innocence
¶ Of thilke Adam / toke we thilke synne original / for of hym / flesshly descended be we alle ⁊ engendred / of vile ⁊ corrupt matere /

and whan the soule / is put in oure body / right anoon is con
tract original synne / and that / þᵗat was erst but oonly peyne of concupiscence / is afterward / bothe peyne ⁊ synne /

And ther fore be we alle yborn sones of wraththe ⁊ of dampnacioūn ꝑperdurable / if it nere baptesme / þᵗat we receyuen / which bynymeþ vs the culpe / but for sothe / the peyne dwelleth with vs as to temptacioūn / which peyne / highte concupiscence /

and this concupiscence / whan it is wrongfully disposed / or ordeyned in man / it maketh hym coueite by couetise of flessh / flesshly synne / by sighte of hise eyen / as to erthely thynges / And eek coueitise of heynesse by pryde of herte

¶ Now as to speke of the firste coueitise / that is concupiscence / after the lawe of oure membres þᵗat weren lawefulliche ymaked ⁊ by rightful Iuge
ment of god /

I seye / for as muche / as man is nat obeisaūnt to god that is his lord / therfore / is the flessh to hym desobeisaūnt
thurgh concupiscence / which þᵗat yet is clepid norissynne of synne ⁊ occasioūn of synne /
therfore / al the while þᵗat a man hath in hym the peyne of concupiscence / it is impossible / but he be tempted som tyme ⁊ moeued in his flessh to synne /
and this thyng may nat faile as longe as he lyueth / it may wel wexe feble and faile by vertu of baptesme ⁊ by the grace of god / thurgh penitence /

but fully ne shal it neuere quenche / þᵗat he ne shal som
tyme / be moeued in hym self/ but if he were al refreided by siknesse / or by malefice of sorcerye / or colde drynkes /
For lo / what seith Seint Paul ▽ the flessh coueiteth agayn the spirit / ⁊ the spirit agayn the flessh / they ben so contrarie ⁊ so stryuen / þᵗat a man may nat alwey do as he wolde

¶ The same Seynt Paul / after his grete penance in water ⁊ in londe / in water by nyght ⁊ by day in gret ꝑperil ⁊ in gret peyne in londe / in famyn ⁊ thurst in cold and clothlees ⁊ ones stooned almoost to the deth /
yet seyde he / Allas .I. kaytif man / who shal delyuere me fro the prison of my kaytif body ▽

And Seint Ierom / whanne he longe tyme hadde woned in desert where as he hadde no compaignye / but of wilde bestes / where as he hadde no mete / but herbes / ⁊ water to his drynke / ne no bed / but the naked erthe / for which his flessh was blak as an Ethiopen for hete ⁊ ney destroyed for cold /.
yet seyde he / þᵗat the brennynge of lecherye / boylede in al his body
¶ Wherfore I woot wel sikerly / þᵗat they ben deceyued / þᵗat seyn / they þᵗat ne be nat tempted in hire body /

Witnesse on Seint Iame the Apostel / that seith / that euery wight is tempted in his owene con
cupiscence / that is to seyn / that euerich of vs / hath matere ⁊ occasion / to be tempted / of the norissynge of synne. þᵗat is in his body ▽
And therfore / seith Seint Iohn the Euᵃungelist ▽ If þᵗat we seyn / þᵗat we be wᵗith oute synne / we deceyuen vs selue and trouthe is nat in vs /
¶ Now shul ye vnderstonde in what manere / þᵗat synne wexeth ⁊ encresceth in man ¶ the firste thyng is thilke norissynge of synne / of which I spak biforn / thilke flesshly concupiscence /
and after that comth the subieccioūn of the deuel / this is to seyn the deueles bely / wᵗithv which he bloweth in man / the fyr of flesshly concupiscence /

and after that a man by
thynketh hym / wheither he wol doon or no / thilke thyng to which he is tempted /

and thanne / if þᵗat a man wᵗith stonde
and wayue the firste entisynges of his flessh / ⁊ of the feend / thanne is it no synne / and if so be / þᵗat he do nat so / thanne feeleth he anon a flawmbe of delit /
and thanne is it good / to be war and kepe hym wel / or ellis he wol falle anon in to consentynge of synne / ⁊ thanne wol he do it/ if he may haue tyme ⁊ place ▽

And of this matere seith Moyses / by the deuel / in this manere ¶ The feend seith ▽ I wol chace ⁊ pʳursue the man / by wikked suggestioūn / and I wol hente hym / by moeuyng or stiryng of synne / ⁊ .I. wol departe my prise / or my preye by de
liberacioūn / ⁊ my lust shal ben acompliced in delit ▽ I wol drawe my swerd in consentynge /
for certes / right as a swerd departeth a thyng in two peces / right so consentynge / departeth god fro man / and thanne wol I sle hym wᵗith myn hand in dede of synne ▽ thus seyth the feend /

for certes / thanne is a man al deed in soule / and thus is synne acompliced / by temp
tacioūn / by delit ⁊ by consentynge / ⁊ thanne is the synne clepid actuel

¶ For sothe / synne is in two maneres / outher it venyal / or dedly synne ▽ Soothly / whan man loueth any creature / moore than IhūIhesu crist oure creatour / thanne is it dedly synne / and venial synne is it if man loue IhūIhesu crist lasse than hym oghte /
for sothe / the dede of this venial synne is ful ꝑperilous / for it amenuseth the loue þᵗat men sholde han to god moore ⁊ moore /

and therfore / if a man charge hym self wᵗith manye swiche venial synnes / certes / but if so be / þᵗat he som tyme descharge hym of hem by shrifte / they mowe ful lightly amenuse in hym / al the loue / þᵗat he hath to IhūIhesu crist
and in this wise skippeth Venial / in to Dedly synne / for certes / the moore þᵗat a man chargeth his soule / with venial synnes / the moore is he enclyned to falle in dedly synne /
And therfore / lat vs nat be necligent to deschargen vs of venial synnes / for the ꝓprouerbe seith / that manye smale maketh a greet ▽

And herkne this ensample ▽ A greet wawe of the See / comth som tyme / wᵗith so greet a violence / that it drencheth the Shipe / and the same harm / doon som tyme / the smale dropes of water / þᵗat entreth thurgh a litel creuesse in to the Thurrok/ ⁊ in the botme of the shipe / if men be so necligent þᵗat men ne descharge hem nat by tyme /
and therfore / al thogh ther be a difference / bitwixe thise two causes of drenchynge / algates the Shipe is dreynt

¶ right so fareth it som tyme of dedly synne / ⁊ of anoyouse venials synnes / whan they multiplie in a man so gretly / þᵗat thilke worldly thynges þᵗat he loueth / thurgh which he synneth venially / is as gret in his herte / as the loue of
god / or moore /
and therfore / the loue of euery thyng þᵗat is nat byset in god / ne doon pⁱrincipally for goddes sake / al þᵗat a man loue it lasse than god / yet is it venial synne /
⁊ dedly synne / whan the loue of any thyng weyeth in the herte of man / as muche / as the loue of god / or moore

¶ Dedly synne / as seith Seynt Augustyn is / whan man turneth his herte fro god / which that is verray souereyn bowntee / þᵗat may nat chaunge / ⁊ yeueth his herte / to a thyng/ þᵗat may chaunge ⁊ flitte /

and certes / that is euery thyng saue god of heuene / for sooth is / þᵗat if a man yeue his loue / the which þᵗat he oweth al to god wᵗith al his herte / vn to a creature / certes as muche of his loue as he yeueth to thilke creature / so muche he bireueth fro god /

and ther
fore / dooth he synne / for he þᵗat is dettour to god / ne yeldeth nat to god al his dette / that is to seyn / al the loue of his herte /

¶ Now sith man vnderstondeth generally / which is venial synne / thanne is it couenable / to tellen specially of synnes / whiche þᵗat many a man ꝑper auenture ne demeth hem nat synnes / ⁊ ne shryueth hym nat of the same thynges / ⁊ yet nathelees they been synnes /
and soothly / as thise clerkes writen / this is to seyn / þᵗat euery tyme þᵗat man eteth or drynketh / moore than suffiseth to the sustenaūnce of his body / in certeyn he dooth synne ▽

and eek / whan he speketh moore than it nedeth / it is synne ▽ eek whan he herkneth nat be
nygnely þe cōmpleynte of the pouere ▽

eek whan he is in heele of body / and wol nat faste / whan oother folk fasten / with outen cause resonable ▽ eek/ whan he slepeth moore than nedeth / or whan he comth by thilke encheson / to late to chirche / or to othere werkes of charitee ▽
eek/ whan he vseth his wyf / with oute souereyn desir of engendrure / to honour of god / or for the entente / to yelde to his wyf the dette of his body ▽

eek whan he wol nat visite the syke / ⁊ the prisoner / if he may ▽ eek / if he loue wyf or child / or oother worldly thyng moore than reson requereth ▽ eek if he flatre / or blaūndise moore than hym oghte / for any necessitee ▽

eek if he amenuse / or withdrawe the almesse of the pouere ▽ eek if he apparaileth his mete / moore deliciously / than nede is / or ete it to hastily / by likerous
nesse ▽
eek/ if he tale vanytes / at chirche / or at goddes seruyce / or þᵗat he be a talkere of ydel wordes / of folye / or of vileynye / for he shal yelde acounte of it at the day of dome ▽
eek / whan he biheteth / or assureth to do thynges / þᵗat he ne may nat ꝑperfourne ▽ eek/ whan þᵗat he / by lightnesse / or folye / mysseyth / or scorneth his neighebore

eek whan he hath any wikked suspecioūn of thyng ther he ne woot of it no sooth
fastnesse ▽
thise thynges / ⁊ mo with oute nombre ben synnes / as seith Seint Augustyn /

¶ Now myghte men axe / wher of þᵗat pryder of cometh pryde. sourdeth ⁊ spryngeth / And I seye som tyme it spryngeth of the goodes of nature / and somtyme of the goodes of fortune / ⁊ som tyme / of the goodes of grace /

¶ As for to speke of heele of
body / certes it passeth ful lightly / ⁊ eek it is ful ofte enchesōn / of the siknesse of the soule / for god woot the flessh is a ful greet enemy to the soule / and therfore / the moore þᵗat the body is hool / the moore be we in ꝑperil to falle ▽
Eke for to pryde hym in hys strengthe of body / it is an heigh folye / for certes / the flessh coueiteth agayn the spirit / ⁊ ay the moore strong þᵗat the flessh is / the sorier may the soule be /
and ouer al this / Strengthe of body ⁊ worldly hardynesse / causeth ful ofte many man / to ꝑperil ⁊ meschaūnce ▽

Eke / for to pryde hym of his genterye / is ful gret folie / for ofte tyme / the genterie of the body / bynymeth the genterie of the soule / ⁊ eek / we ben alle / of .o. fader ⁊ of o moder / ⁊ alle we ben of o nature roten / and corrupt bothe riche ⁊ pouere /

for truste wel / þᵗat ouer what man þᵗat synne hath maistrye / he is verray cherl to synne
¶ Now / ben ther general signes of gentilesse / as eschewynge of vice / or rybaudye ⁊ seruage of synne / in word / in werk / and contenaūnce /
⁊ vsynge vertu / curteisye / ⁊ clennesse / ⁊ to be liberal / that is to seyn / large by mesure / for thilke that passeth mesure / is folye ⁊ synne ▽

Certes also / who þᵗat prydeth hym in the goodes of fortune / he is a ful gret fool / for som tyme / is a man a gret lord by the morwe / þᵗat is a kaytif ⁊ a wrecche / er it be nyght
and som tyme / the richesse of a man is cause of his deeth / somtyme the delices of a man / ben cause of the greuous maladie / thurgh which he dyeth ▽
Certes / the cōmmendacioūn of the peple / is som tyme ful fals / ⁊ ful brotil for to triste / this day they preise / to morwe they blame /
god woot desir to haue the cōmmendacioūn eek of peple / hath caused deth / to many a bisy man

¶ Now wol I speken of the remedye agayns this fouleremedies for enuie. synne of Enuye ¶ first is the loue of god principal / and louynge of hym self / ⁊ of his neighebore / for soothly / that oon ne may nat ben wᵗith outhen that oother /

and truste wel / þᵗat in the name of thy neighebore / thow shalt vnderstonde / the name of thy brother / for certes / alle we haue o fader flesshly ⁊ o moder / that is to seyn Adam and Eue / ⁊ eek o fader spirituel / that is god of heuene /
thy neighebore artow holden for to loue ⁊ wilne hym alle goodnesse / and ther fore seith god / loue thy neighebore as thy self / that is to seyn / to sauacion / bothe of lyf/ and soule /

⁊ moore
ouer / thow shalt loue hym in word / ⁊ benygne amonestynge / ⁊ chastisynge / ⁊ conforte hym / in hise anoyes ⁊ preye for hym wᵗith al thyn herte ▽
And in dede / thow shalt loue hym in swich wise / þᵗat thow shalt doon to hym in charitee / as thow woldest þᵗat were doon to thyn owene ꝑpersone /
and therfore / thow ne shalt doon hym no damage in wikked word / ne harm in his body / ne in his catel / ne in his soule by entisynge of wikked ensample
¶ Thow shalt nat eek/ desiren his wyf ne none of hyse thynges ¶ Vnderstoond eek þᵗat in the name of neighebore / is cōmprehended his enemy /
certes man shal loue his enemy for the comandement of god / and soothly / thy freend shaltow loue in god ▽

I seye / thyn enemy shaltow loue for goddes sake / by his comande
ment / for if it were resoūn / þᵗat man sholde hate his enemy / for sothe / god nolde nat receyuen vs to his loue þᵗat ben hise enemys /
¶ Agayns .iij. manere of wronges þᵗat his enemy dooth to hym / he shal doon .iij. thynges / as thus /
▽ Agayns hate ⁊ rancour of herte / he shal loue hym in herte / ▽ Agayns chidynge ⁊ wikked wordes / he shal preye for his enemy ▽ Agayns the wikked dede of his enemy / he shal doon hym bountee /

for crist seith / loueth youre enemys / ⁊ preieth for hem / þᵗat speke yow harm / ⁊ eek for hem / þᵗat yow chacen and pursuen / and dooth bountee / to hem þᵗat yow haten ¶ Lo thus comandeth vs oure lord IhūIhesu crist to do to oure enemys /

for soothly / nature dryueth vs to louen oure frendes / ⁊ ꝑparfey oure enemys / han moore nede to loue / than oure frendes / ⁊ they þᵗat moore nede haue / certes to hem shal men doon good
nesse /
and certes in thilke dede haue we remembraūnce of the loue of IhūIhesu crist þᵗat deyde for hise enemys /
and in as muche as thilke loue is the moore greuous to ꝑparfourne / so muche is the moore gret the merite / and therfore the louynge of of oure enemy / hath confounded the venym of the deuel /
for right / as the deuel is desconfited by humylitee / right so is he wownded to the deth / by the loue of oure enemy /

the speces of this pas shullen ben moore largely declared / in hire chapitres folwynge

anon he wole cōmmunely fynde hym matere of wraththe / in word or in dede / agayns hym / to whom he hath enuye /

¶ This synne of Ire / after the discryuyng of Seint Augustyn / is wikked wil to ben auenged / by word / or by dede
¶ Ire after the philosophre / is the feruent blood of man / yquyked in his herte / thurgh which / he wole harm / to hym þᵗat he hateth /
for certes the herte of man / by eschawfynge ⁊ moeuynge of his blood / wexeth so trouble / þᵗat he is out of alle Iugement of resoūn //
But ye shal vnderstonde / þᵗat Ire is in two maneres ▽ that oon of hem is good ⁊ that oother is wikke ▽

the goode Ire is / by Ialowsie of goodnesse / thurgh which / a man is wrooth wᵗith wikkednesse ⁊ agayns wikkednesse / and ther
fore seith a wys / that Ire is bet than pley ▽

this Ire is wᵗith debonairetee / ⁊ it is wroth wᵗith oute bitternesse / nat wroth agayns the man / but wroth / wᵗith the mysdede of the man / as seith the ꝓprophete Dauid ¶ Irascimini ⁊ nolite peccare
¶ Now vnderstondeth / þᵗat wikked Ire / is in .ij. maneres ▽ that is to seyn / sodeyn Ire or hastif Ire with oute auysement ⁊ consentynge of his reson /

the Menyng ⁊ the sens of this is / þᵗat the reson of a man ne con

Another Ire / is ful wikked / þᵗat comth of felonye of herte auysed / ⁊ cast bifore wᵗith wikked wil to do vengeaūnce / ⁊ ther to his resoūn consenteth / and soothly / this is dedly synne

nesse of the deuel / ⁊ bynymeth the man fro god / þᵗat is his rightful lord ▽
this Ire / is a ful gret plesaūnce to the deuel / for it is the deueles forneys / þᵗat is eschawfed wᵗith the fyr of helle /
for certes / right so as fyr is moore myghty to destroye erthely thynges / than another Element; right so Ire is myghty / to destroye alle spirituel thynges ▽
